{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=January 2011}} {{advert|date=January 2011}} }} {{lowercase}} {{Infobox company | name = aisle411 | logo = File:Aisle411_logo.jpg | type = | industry = [[Mobile application development]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 2008 | founders = Nathan Pettyjohn, Matthew Kulig | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[St. Louis, Missouri]] | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{URL|http://aisle411.com/}} }} '''aisle411 Inc.''' is a [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] based company that has developed a [[consumer]] service called '''aisle411''', which allows customers to use their phones to find products in stores. Founded in 2008 by [[Nathan Pettyjohn]] (Founder) and [[Matthew Kulig]] (Co-Founder), aisle411 entered the market in August 2009 with a mobile service that allowed consumers to search retail stores for product locations inside stores using their [[mobile phone]]s.
==History== In August 2009, aisle411 launched its original product location service in St. Louis, MO area Ace Hardware [[Ace Hardware]] locations and Springfield, MO area Price Cutter grocery stores. In 2010, aisle411 launched its mobile smartphone service with Shop 'n Save, a grocery chain owned by Supervalu [[SuperValu (United States)|Supervalu]] and Schnucks [[Schnucks]] grocery stores in the St. Louis, MO area. In September 2011, WinCo Foods [[WinCo Foods]] partnered with aisle411 to deploy its technology chainwide to its 79 stores. In December 2011, Hyvee [[Hy-Vee]], a grocery chain of 235 store locations launched the aisle411 platform within their mobile iPhone and Android applications allowing shoppers to map products, lists, and weekly ads. In September 2012, Walgreens [[Walgreens|Walgreens Co.]] launched the aisle411 platform in its iPhone and Android mobile applications, making Walgreens in-store inventory searchable and mappable in over 7,800 locations.
In September 2012, aisle411 acquired the technology assets of [https://web.archive.org/web/20130510114750/http://www.wilocate.net/ WiLocate], adding indoor mobile device positioning technology to its service offering.<ref>http://supermarketnews.com/latest-news/shop-n-save-supports-updated-navigation-app</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.progressivegrocer.com/top-stories/headlines/technology/id33712/winco-foods-deploys-mobile-in-store-navigation-service/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-12-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425234316/http://www.progressivegrocer.com/top-stories/headlines/technology/id33712/winco-foods-deploys-mobile-in-store-navigation-service |archive-date=2012-04-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>http://go.bloomberg.com/tech-blog/2012-07-16-looking-for-pain-relief-app-tells-you-which-aisle-in-walgreens/</ref><ref>http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/blog/BizNext/2012/09/with-acquisition-aisle411-wants-to.html</ref>
In September 2013, aisle411 raised $6.3 million in its first round of financing - led by St. Louis-based Cultivation Capital - to help the company scale, meet demand and expand retail partnerships.<ref>https://venturebeat.com/2013/09/04/aisle411-raises-6-3m-to-create-digital-maps-of-physical-stores/</ref> Another company that has invested in aisle411 includes [[Billiken Angels Network]].
==Services== '''aisle411''' allows consumers with [[Smart Phone]]s to pull up a map pinpointing the aisle and location of the object of their desire in a particular store. The aisle411 platform is made available for licensing to retailers, and 3rd parties through an API and Map SDK. Shoppers can also use the app to scan [[barcode]]s to read product reviews and find out about in-store [[Discounts and allowances|discounts]] and promotions. aisle411 went live in the [[iTunes Store]] around Thanksgiving.<ref>http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/article_c791a6dd-f5e1-5311-bf44-535adf51184f.html</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== Official website [http://www.aisle411.com www.aisle411.com]
[[Category:Promotion and marketing communications]] [[Category:Companies established in 2008]]
{{business-stub}}

revision.text:
{{condense|date=October 2013}} '''Abraham "Bram" van Leeuwen''', also known as '''Prince of Lignac''' ([[Rotterdam]], 18 July 1918 - [[Málaga]], 27 May 2001) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] businessman and high-profile millionaire.
==Poor start== Van Leeuwen grew up in Rotterdam under impoverished circumstances. The humiliation that he and only just one other kid had to borrow his schoolbooks made a big impression on him. This memory was one of the reasons Van Leeuwen promised himself to become rich and successful in life. He founded '''NTI: Nederlands Talen Instituut''', one of the first language training companies. Just before and during [[World War II]] Van Leeuwen wrote an English training course - which was in great demand at that time. To receive permission from the [[Germany|German]] occupiers to start his company he was forced to develop a German course as well. He also founded [[Lecturama]], a Dutch publisher specialized in collecting and (re)publishing special series and popular books and doing so making these publications obtainable for the mass market.<ref>short info on {{cite web |url=http://www.lecturama.nl/aanbiedingen/lecturama/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080717013549/http://www.lecturama.nl/aanbiedingen/lecturama/ |archivedate=2008-07-17 |df= }} on companies website</ref> After the war Van Leeuwen continued starting companies.
Van Leeuwen sold his companies at the best time. The '''NTI''' and '''Lecturama''' were sold to the Dutch [[Vendex]] concern in the 1970s for 450 million [[Dutch Guilder|Dutch guilders]] and made him his huge fortune.<ref name="tele">[[De Telegraaf]] website about the death of the [http://krant.telegraaf.nl/krant/archief/20010531/teksten/bin.leeuwen.bram.vermogen.html Prince of Lignac], visited 16 July 2008</ref>
==Jetset== Van Leeuwen was seen as an eccentric member of the jet set, living on board of his mega-yacht '''New Horizon L''' built by [[Feadship]]/[[Royal van Lent shipyard]]. He received many guests on board of this 60 meter long ship, where even the air-outlets are said to be solid gold. Rumors say Van Leeuwen bought the title '''Prince de Lignac''' but he always denied this and claimed he received it from a [[prince]] he met during the war. According again to Van Leeuwen his title was acknowledged by the São Paulo Aristocracy Court in 1966<ref name="tele"/>
==Lifestyle== Van Leeuwen was openly [[homosexual]], which was extremely controversial in the years immediately following World War Two. This openness drew substantial attention from [[gossip]] magazines, as did his penchant for hosting extremely lavish parties, and the fact that the servants on his yacht were exclusively Asian males; when asked why he hired only Asian males for these positions, van Leeuwen said only that they "serve the best"<ref>Internetarchive.org version of 2008 of Inmemoriam.be website about{{cite web|url=http://www.inmemoriam.be/bvdetail.asp?bvid=241 |title=Bram van Leeuwen |accessdate=2008-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080701004133/http://www.inmemoriam.be/bvdetail.asp?bvid=241 |archivedate=2008-07-01 |df= }} , link updated 10-10-2010</ref>
==Death== Van Leeuwen died on his yacht at the age of 82 years. In his will Van Leeuwen left a small part of his fortune to his longtime partner Hans Verver (Euro 35 million + the yacht). The majority (Euro 100 million) was left to the ''Stichting Van Leeuwen Van Lignac'' <ref>Bron: [[Quote Magazine]] edition March 2007.</ref> This foundation aims to help the physical and mental health of the people of [[Rotterdam]], focusing on the elderly and/or lonely people and young children and [[orphans]].<ref>Annual report of Volkskracht and related foundations, [http://www.volkskracht.nl/Volkskracht/VolkskrachtVerslag2005.pdf Report 2005] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521121008/http://www.volkskracht.nl/Volkskracht/VolkskrachtVerslag2005.pdf |date=May 21, 2009 }}, page 30+</ref>
==Sources== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leeuwen, Bram Van}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:LGBT businesspeople from the Netherlands]] [[Category:People from Rotterdam]]

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Made to Order|the television program|Made to Order (television series)}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2011}}
'''Build to order''' ('''BTO''') and sometimes referred to as '''make to order''' or '''made to order''' ('''MTO'''), is a [[Mass production|production]] approach where products are not built until a confirmed order for products is received. BTO is the oldest style of [[order fulfillment]] and is the most appropriate approach used for ''highly customized'' or ''low volume'' products.
"Made to order" products are common in the food service industry, such as at restaurants.
==Overview== This approach is considered good for [[Mass customization|highly configured]] products, e.g. [[automobile]]s,<ref>Holweg and Pil, 2004, pg.</ref><ref>Parry and Graves, 2008, pg.</ref> [[bicycles]], [[Server (computing)|computer servers]], or for products where holding inventories is very expensive, e.g. [[aircraft]].
In an automotive context, BTO is a demand driven production approach where a product is scheduled and built in response to a confirmed order received for it from a final customer.<ref name=Roehrich>Roehrich, J.K.; Parry, G. and Graves, A. (2011), [http://www.inderscience.com/search/index.php?action=record&rec_id=40869. Implementing build-to-order strategies: enablers and barriers in the European automotive industry], ''International Journal of Automotive Technology and Management''. 11(3): 221-235</ref> The final customer refers to a known individual owner and excludes all orders by the [[original equipment manufacturer]] (OEM), national sales companies (NSC), dealers or point of sales, bulk orders or other intermediaries in the [[supply chain]]. BTO excludes the order amendment function, whereby forecast orders in the pipeline are amended to customer requirements, as this is seen as another level of sophistication for a [[build to stock]] (BTS) system (also known as build to forecast (BTF)).
BTS is the dominant approach used today across many industries and refers to products that are built before a final purchaser has been identified, with production volume driven by historical demand information.<ref>Parry and Graves, 2008, pg.</ref> This high stock level, endemic across the auto industry allows some dealers to find an exact or very close match to the customer’s desired vehicle within the dealer networks and supplier parks. The vehicle can then be delivered as soon as transport can be arranged. This has been used to justify stock levels. Whilst providing a rapid response to customer demand, the approach is expensive, mainly in terms of stock, but also transportation as finished goods are rarely where they are required. Holding stock of such a high cash value as finished goods is a key driver of the current crisis in the automotive industry - a crisis that could be eased by implementation of a BTO system.<ref name=Roehrich />
A BTO system does not mean that all suppliers in the supplier chain should be producing only when a customer order has been confirmed. Clearly, it would not make economic sense for a manufacturer of low value high volume parts to employ BTO. It is appropriate that these should be identified and built to a supplier order, effectively BTS. Part of the challenge in a BTO supplier network is in the identification of which suppliers should be BTO and which BTS. The point in the supply chain when this change occurs is called the ‘decoupling point’. Currently, the majority of automotive supply chains lack a decoupling point and the dominant BTS approach has resulted in billions of dollars of capital being tied up in stock in the supply chain.<ref>Parry and Graves, 2008, pg.</ref>
Some firms build all their products to order while others practice (BTS). Given the widespread proliferation of products, there are a number of [[Manufacturing|manufacturers]] taking a combined approach, where some items are BTS and others are BTO, which is commonly referred to as "hybrid BTO".<ref>Holweg and Pil, 2001, pg.</ref>
The main advantages of the BTO approach in environments of high product variety is the ability to supply the customer with the exact product specification required, the reduction in sales discounts and finished good inventory, as well a reduction in stock obsolescence risk. The main disadvantage of BTO is manufacturers are susceptible to market demand fluctuations leading to a reduced capacity utilization in manufacturing. Hence, to ensure an effective use of production resources, a BTO approach should be coupled with proactive demand management. Finding the correct and appropriate balance of BTO and BTS to maintain stock levels appropriate to both the market requirement and operational stability is a current area of academic research.
Related approaches to BTO include the Engineer to Order (ETO) approach, where after an order is received, a part of or the whole design is done, as well as the Assemble to Order (ATO). Together with the BTS approach, these strategies form the spectrum of [[order fulfillment]] strategies a firm can adopt.
==See also== * [[Bespoke]] * [[Configurator]] * [[Print on demand]] * [[Mass customization]] * [[Sales Order]] * [[Assemble-to-order system]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Holweg, M. and Pil, F. (2001), ‘Successful Build-to-Order Strategies start with the Customer’, MIT Sloan Management Review, Fall issue, Vol. 43, No. 1, p. 74-83 [https://web.archive.org/web/20070216112100/http://sloanreview.mit.edu/smr/issue/2001/fall/7/] *Holweg, M. and Pil, F. (2004), ‘The Second Century: Reconnecting Customer and Value Chain through Build-to-Order’, Cambridge, MA and London, UK: The MIT Press. [https://web.archive.org/web/20071225140248/http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=10750] *[[Glenn Parry|Parry]], G. and Graves, A., Eds. (2008), 'Build to Order: The Road to the 5-Day Car', London: Springer Verlag. [https://www.springer.com/engineering/mechanical+eng/book/978-1-84800-224-1] *Kabaivanova, S. (2015), 'Made To Order - the new fashion formula in men's suit market. [http://made-to-measure-suits.bgfashion.net/article/10282/44/Made-To-Order-the-new-fashion-formula-in-mens-suit-market]
{{Production Approaches}} [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Modes of production]]

{{redirect|The Bushes|other uses|Bush (disambiguation)}} {{redirect|Bushian|uses related to other people|Bush (surname)}} {{Infobox family | name = Bush family | image = | crest = [[File:George W. Bush and family.jpg|frameless|upright=1.35]] | caption = The Bush family in the [[Red Room (White House)|Red Room]] of the White House (January 2005) seated from left to right: [[Marvin P. Bush|Marvin Bush]], [[Laura Bush]], [[George W. Bush]], [[Barbara Bush]], [[George H. W. Bush]], [[Jeb Bush]]. Also pictured, from left: Georgia Grace Koch, Margaret Bush, Charles Walker Bush, [[Jenna Bush Hager]], [[Dorothy Bush Koch|Doro Bush]], [[Barbara Bush (born 1981)|Barbara Pierce Bush]], [[Robert P. Koch]], Pierce Bush, Maria Bush, [[Neil Bush]], Ashley Bush, Sam LeBlond, Robert Koch, Nancy Ellis LeBlond, John "Jebby" Bush, Amanda Bush, [[George P. [[Prairie Chapel Ranch]] (McLennan County, Texas) | meaning = | footnotes = |ethnicity=[[English Americans|English]] and [[German Americans|German]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wargs.com/political/bush.html |title=Ancestry of George W. Bush |accessdate=11 Sep 2014 |last=Reitwiesner |first=William Addams |authorlink=William Addams Reitwiesner}} }} The '''Bush family''' is an American family that is prominent in the fields of politics, sports, entertainment, and business, founded by [[Obadiah Bush]] and Harriet Smith. Best known for its involvement in politics, the family has held various national and state offices spanning across four generations, including a U.S. Senator, [[Prescott Bush]], a Governor, [[Jeb Bush]], and two U.S. Presidents—one having also served as Vice President, [[George H. W. Bush]], while the other was also a Governor, [[George W. Bush]]. Other family members include a [[National Football League]] (NFL) executive, [[Joe Ellis]], and two nationally known TV personalities, [[Billy Bush]] and [[Jenna Bush Hager]]. [[Peter Schweizer]], author of a biography of the family, has described the Bushes as "the most successful political [[dynasty]] in American history".{{cite news|url=http://washtimes.com/national/20050119-123016-5212r.htm |title=Rise of 'dynasty' quick, far-reaching|author=Joseph Curl|publisher=[[The Washington Times]]|date=January 20, 2005|accessdate=2006-11-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319124218/http://washtimes.com/national/20050119-123016-5212r.htm|archivedate=2006-03-19}} According to some online sources,{{cite web|url=http://www.wargs.com/political/bush.html |title=Ancestry of George W. Bush |accessdate=11 Sep 2014 |last=Reitwiesner |first=William Addams |authorlink=William Addams Reitwiesner}} the Bush family is of primarily [[English people|English]] and [[Germans|German]] descent. The Bush family traces its European origin to the 17th century, with Samuel Bush being their first American-born ancestor, in 1647. ==Relations== * [[James Smith Bush]] (1825–1889), father of [[Samuel P. Bush]] ** [[Samuel P. Bush|Samuel Prescott Bush]] (1863–1948), father of [[Prescott Bush]] and son of [[James Smith Bush]] ** Flora Sheldon Bush (1870–1920), wife of Samuel P. Bush (married June 20, 1894) and mother to Prescott Bush *** [[Prescott Bush|Prescott Sheldon Bush]] (1895–1972), Samuel P. Bush's son, served as a [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] from [[Connecticut]]; former chairman of the [[USGA]]. *** Dorothy Wear Walker Bush (1901–1992), wife of Prescott, was a daughter of [[George Herbert Walker]] of the well-connected [[List of political families of the United States#Walker family|Walker family]] of bankers and businessmen, served as informal [[First Family of the United States|First Mother]] from 1989, her son's inauguration during the beginning of his presidency until her death in 1992, in her son's final year of the presidency. **** Prescott Sheldon "Pressy" Bush Jr. (1922–2010), Prescott Bush's eldest son, who served as chairman of the United States-China Chamber of Commerce; married to Elizabeth "Beth" Kauffman ({{abbr|1922|June 19, 1922}}–{{abbr|2014|February 20, 2014}}) on December 30, 1944https://www.currentobituary.com/obit/80538https://patch.com/connecticut/greenwich/beth-bush-91-community-activist-widow-of-prescott-bush-ii ***** Prescott Sheldon Bush III ({{abbr|1945|November 4, 1945}}–{{abbr|2009|July 24, 2009}}), son of Prescott Bush Jr.; married to Francesca Emerson Farr on June 28, 1970https://www.nytimes.com/1970/06/28/archives/francesca-farr-is-bride-of-prescott-s-bush-3d.html ***** Kelsey Bush-Nadeau, daughter of Prescott Bush Jr.; married to Philip Gerald Nadeau on May 25, 1974https://www.nytimes.com/1974/03/17/archives/may-bridal-set-by-miss-bush-philip-nadeau.htmlhttps://www.nytimes.com/1974/05/26/archives/philip-gerald-nadeau-marries-kelsev-bush.html ****** Elizabeth Nadeau, daughter of Kelsey Bush-Nadeau ****** Katherine Nadeau, daughter of Kelsey Bush-Nadeau ****** William F. Nadeau, son of Kelsey Bush-Nadeau, [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]] [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]]; married to Lydia Jean Strickland ******* Ellie Nadeau, daughter of William F. Nadeau ****** Prescott Nadeau, son of Kelsey Bush-Nadeau ***** James Laurence "Jamie" Bush, son of Prescott Bush Jr.; married to Susan C. "Sue" Bush ****** Sarah Bush Richey, daughter of James L. Bush; married to William "Drake" Richey ******* Draper Dennis Richey (born February 19, 2012)https://deerfield.edu/alumni/class-notes/2012/06/baby/10198210 ******* George Laurence Richey (born May 26, 2014)https://deerfield.edu/alumni/class-notes/2014/08/welcoming-a-new-baby/10213552 ****** Samuel P. Bush, son of James L. Bush **** [[George H. W. Bush|George Herbert Walker Bush]] (1924–2018), Prescott Bush Sr.'s second son; 41st [[President of the United States]], 43rd [[Vice President of the United States]] under [[Ronald Reagan]], a Representative from [[Texas]], and [[Central Intelligence Agency]] director, among other political and diplomatic posts **** [[Barbara Bush|Barbara Pierce Bush]] (1925–2018), wife of George H. W.; daughter of publisher [[Marvin Pierce]], distant cousin of 14th U.S. President Franklin Pierce, [[Second Lady of the United States|Second Lady]] and later [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] of the U.S. ***** [[George W. W. Bush picnics on the lawn of his Kennebunkport home with his family, 1988]] ***** [[Laura Bush|Laura Lane Welch Bush]] (born 1946), wife of George W. and [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]]; earlier a teacher ****** [[Barbara Bush (born 1981)|Barbara Pierce Bush]] (born 1981), daughter of George and Laura Bush and twin sister of Jenna, health care activist and chair of Global Health Corps.; married to Craig Louis Coyne ****** [[Jenna Bush Hager|Jenna Welch Bush Hager]] (born 1981), daughter of George and Laura and twin sister of Barbara, [[NBC News]] correspondent; married to Henry Chase Hager, son of former [[Lieutenant Governor of Virginia]] [[John H. Hager]] ******* Margaret Laura "Mila" Hager (born April 13, 2013), daughter of Jenna Bush Hager ******* Poppy Louise Hager (born August 13, 2015), daughter of Jenna Bush Hager ***** [[Pauline Robinson Bush|Pauline Robinson "Robin" Bush]] (1949–1953), George H. W. Bush's second child and first daughter; died of leukemia near [[school-age]] ***** [[Jeb Bush|John Ellis "Jeb" Bush]] (born 1953), George H. W. Bush's second son,{{cite web|last1=Cirilli|first1=Kevin|title=Blunt Barbara Bush tells Jeb: You're not my favorite son|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/245650-barbara-bush-bashes-son-jeb-youre-not-my-favorite|website=The Hill|accessdate=February 12, 2016}} 43rd [[Governor of Florida]]; married to [[Columba Bush|Columba Garnica Gallo]] ****** [[George P. Bush|George Prescott Bush]] (born 1976), son of Jeb Bush, 28th commissioner of the [[Texas General Land Office]] since 2015; married to Amanda Williams ******* Prescott Walker Bush (born June 3, 2013), son of George P. Bush ******* John William Bush (born April 13, 2015), son of George P. Bush ****** Noelle Lucila Bush (born 1977), daughter of Jeb Bush ****** John Ellis "Jebby" Bush Jr. (born 1983), son of Jeb Bush; married to Sandra Mary Algudady ******* Georgia Helena Walker Bush (born 2011), daughter of Jebby Bush ******* Vivian Alexandra Columba Bush (born 2014), daughter of Jebby Bush ***** [[Neil Bush|Neil Mallon Bush]] (born 1955), third son of George H. W. Bush and brother of Pres. George W. Bush; businessman; married Sharon Smith, & divorced in April 2003; married to Maria Andrews {{as of|2004|lc=yes}} ****** [[Lauren Bush|Lauren Pierce Bush Lauren]] (born 1984), daughter of Neil Bush and [[Sharon Smith Bush|Sharon Smith]]; model for [[Tommy Hilfiger]]; married to [[David Lauren]] ******* James Richard Lauren (born November 21, 2015), son of Lauren Bush Lauren ******* Max Walker Lauren (born April 19, 2018), son of Lauren Bush Lauren ****** Pierce Mallon Bush (born 1986), son of Neil Bush and [[Sharon Smith Bush|Sharon Smith]]; married to Sarah Beth Melton ****** Ashley Walker Bush (born 1989), daughter of Neil Bush and [[Sharon Smith Bush|Sharon Smith]] ***** [[Marvin Bush|Marvin Pierce Bush]] (born 1956), fourth son of George H. W. Bush, and brother of George W. Bush; [[venture capitalist]]; married to Margaret Conway (née Molster); adopted children: daughter Marshall, and son Walker ***** [[Dorothy Bush Koch|Dorothy Walker Bush Koch]] (born 1959), second daughter of George H. W. Bush and sister of President George W. Bush; married to, and in 1990 divorced from, William LeBlond; married to [[Bobby Koch]], wine lobbyist ****** Samuel Bush LeBlond (born 1984), son of Dorothy Bush Koch and William LeBlond ****** Nancy Ellis "Ellie" LeBlond (born 1986), daughter of Dorothy Bush Koch and William LeBlond; married to Nick Sosa ****** Robert David Koch (born 1993), son of Dorothy Bush Koch and Bobby Koch ****** Georgia Grace "Gigi" Koch (born 1996), daughter of Dorothy Bush Koch and Bobby Koch **** [[Nancy Walker Bush Ellis]] (born 1926), Prescott Bush Sr.'s third child and only daughter, widow of [[Alexander Ellis II]] (1922-1989), an insurance executive ***** [[Alexander Ellis III]] (born 1949), son of Nancy Bush Ellis and Alexander Ellis II ***** [[John Prescott Ellis]] (born 1953), son of Nancy Bush Ellis and Alexander Ellis II; media consultant ***** [[Joe Ellis|Josiah "Joe" Ellis]] (born 1958), son of Nancy Bush Ellis and Alexander Ellis II; President, Chairman and CEO of the [[Denver Broncos]], two-time [[Super Bowl]] champion as a member of the Broncos' front office **** [[Jonathan Bush|Jonathan James Bush]] (born 1931), Prescott Bush Sr.'s fourth child; banker; married to Josephine Bush (née Bradley) ***** [[Jonathan S. Bush]] (born 1969), son of Jonathan Bush, CEO of [[athenahealth]] ***** [[Billy Bush|William Hall "Billy" Bush]] (born 1971), son of Jonathan Bush; a former ''[[Access Hollywood]]'' host; forced out of [[NBC news|NBC-news]] job October 2016 in [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|allegations about Donald Trump]] **** [[William H. T. Bush|William Henry Trotter "Bucky" Bush]] (1938—2018), Prescott Bush Sr.'s fifth child; banker and executive ===Ancestors=== [[File:Five members of the Bush family (June 2001).jpg|thumb|[[Barbara Bush]], [[Jeb Bush]], [[George H. W. Bush]], [[Laura Bush]], [[George W. Bush]] and Hall of Fame pitcher [[Bob Feller]] watch [[tee ball]] on the [[White House]] lawn]] ====Patrilineal line==== * John Bush Sr (1510–1590) ** John Bush Jr (1535–1595) ***Reynold Bush (1566–unknown) **** John Bush III (1593–1670), born in [[Messing]], Essex, England and the last English ancestor ***** Samuel Bush (1647–1733) ****** Richard Bush (c. 1676–1732 in [[Bristol, Rhode Island|Bristol]], [[Plymouth Colony]]) ******* Timothy Bush (1728–1821 in [[Springport, New York]]) may have been the son of Richard Bush.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} ******** Timothy Bush Jr. (1761–1850 in [[Penfield, New York]]) was the son of Timothy Bush. ********* [[Obadiah Bush|Obadiah Newcomb Bush]] (January 28, 1797 – 1851) was the son of blacksmith Timothy Bush Jr. and was an American prospector and businessman. **********[[James Smith Bush]] (1825–1889), an attorney and [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopal]] priest in [[New Jersey]], [[California]], and [[New York (state)|New York]], was the son of Obadiah Bush and the father of [[Samuel Prescott Bush]], ******** John Bush (1761-unknown) ********* [[George Bush (biblical scholar)|George Bush]] (1796–1859) was a biblical scholar and [[The New Church|Swedenborgian]] minister who wrote the book ''[[Muhammad|Life of Mohammed]]'', ====Other notable relatives==== * [[Robert Bolling|Col. Robert Bolling Sr.]] (1646–1709) of [[Kippax Plantation]] was an Early American settler in the colony of [[Virginia]] whose son, [[Robert Bolling Jr.]], was a Bush family ancestor. Bolling Sr. later had children with [[Jane Rolfe]], the granddaughter of [[Pocahontas]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} * [[Edith Wilson]] (1872–1961), second wife of U.S. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] was also descended from Col. Robert Bolling Sr. so therefore was distantly related to the Bush family. * [[Wild Bill Hickok]] (1837–1876) was a second cousin three times removed of [[Prescott Bush]]. * [[John Howland]] (1592/1593–1672/1673) and [[Elizabeth Tilley]] (1607-1687), ''Mayflower'' passengers, through their daughter Hope.http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=glencoe&id=I607 Ancestry.com * [[Thomas Hinckley|Gov. Thomas Hinckley]] (1618–1706) was a Plymouth Colony governor, and a seventh generation great-grandfather of [[Prescott Sheldon Bush]], so therefore a direct ancestor of all of his descendants including his son [[George H. W. Bush]] and grandson [[George W. Bush]]. * [[Mary Parker (Salem witch trials)|Mary Parker]] (1637–1692) was executed by hanging in 1692 for witchcraft in the [[Salem witch trials|Salem Witch Trials]].[http://jefferson.village.virginia.edu:8090/saxon/servlet/SaxonServlet?source=salem/texts/bios.xml&style=salem/xsl/dynaxml.xsl&chunk.id=b42&clear-stylesheet-cache=yes Kelly, Jacqueline. "The Untold Story of Mary Ayer Parker: Gossip and Confusion in 1692."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202192430/http://jefferson.village.virginia.edu:8090/saxon/servlet/SaxonServlet?source=salem%2Ftexts%2Fbios.xml&style=salem%2Fxsl%2Fdynaxml.xsl&chunk.id=b42&clear-stylesheet-cache=yes |date=February 2, 2009 }} Revised for presentation at the Berkshire Conference. June 2005.Robinson, Enders A. "Salem Witchcraft and Hawthorne's House of Seven Gables." pp. 251–5. Bowie, Md.: Heritage Books. 1992. * Through John May and his wife Prudence Bridge (great-great-grandparents of [[Obadiah Bush|Obadiah Newcomb Bush]]), the family is related to U.S. Attorney General [[Charles Bonaparte (Attorney General)|Charles Bonaparte]] (1851–1921), U.S. Vice President [[Charles G. Dawes|Charles Gates Dawes]] (1865–1951), actress [[Blanche Oelrichs]] (who was also known by the pseudonym "Michael Strange") (1890–1950), and author [[Louisa May Alcott]] (1832–1888). *[[Douglas MacArthur]] (1880–1964), American [[five-star rank|five star]] general and [[Field Marshal]] of the Philippine Army who was the [[Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers]] in the [[Pacific War|Pacific theater]] during [[World War II]] was distantly related to the Bush family.{{cite web|url=http://famouskin.com/famous-kin-chart.php?name=3103+george+w+bush&kin=17573+douglas+macarthur|title=Family relationship of George W. Bush and General Douglas MacArthur via John Gallop Jr..|website=famouskin.com}} ===Connections to other prominent families=== [[File:George H.W. and George W. Bush in Beijing 2008.jpg|thumb|[[George W. Bush]] and [[George H. W. Bush]] in Beijing, 2008]] [[George Herbert Walker|George Herbert "Bert" Walker]] (1875–1953) was a wealthy American banker and businessman. His daughter Dorothy married [[Prescott Bush]], making him the grandfather of the 41st President [[George H. W. Bush]] and the great-grandfather of the 43rd President [[George W. Bush]]. He is also the namesake of the [[Walker Cup]], a men's amateur golf trophy contested in odd-numbered years between a U.S. team and a combined [[United Kingdom|Great Britain]] and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] side. Flora Sheldon, wife of [[Samuel P. Bush]], was a distant descendant of the [[Livingston family|Livingston]], [[Schuyler family|Schuyler]], and [[Wilhelmus Beekman|Beekman]] families, prominent [[New Netherland]] merchant and political patrician families. ===Family tree=== {{Tree list}} * Timothy Bush Jr., m. Lydia Newcomb ** {{Tree list/final branch}} [[Obadiah Bush|Obadiah Newcomb Bush]] (1797–1851), m. Harriet Smith *** {{Tree list/final branch}} [[James Smith Bush]], m. Bush|William Henry Trotter Bush]] ***** Robert Sheldon Bush ***** Mary Eleanor Bush ***** Margaret Livingston Bush ***** {{Tree list/final branch}} James Smith Bush {{Tree list/end}} Sources:{{citation|page = 9|chapter = Bush Family Tree|url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=NRKERJ2D5OQC&oi=fnd&pg=PT9&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = Duty, Honor, Country: The Life and Legacy of Prescott Bush|first = Mickey|last = Herskowitz|publisher = [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]]|year = 2003|isbn = 9781401600099}}{{citation|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNO3WVTokk0C&pg=PA4774#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = The Family Forest Descendants of Lady Joan Beaufort|first = Bruce|last = Harrison|publisher = Millisecond Publishing Company, Inc.|place = [[Kamuela, Hawaii]]|year = 2005}}{{citation|first = Kitty|last = Kelley|authorlink = Kitty Kelley|year = 2004|isbn = 9781407095691|url = http://www.randomhouse.com/doubleday/thefamily/media/thefamily_family_tree.pdf|title = The Family: The Real Story of the Bush Dynasty|chapter = Bush / Walker / Pierce / Robinson / Family Tree|publisher = [[Random House]]}}{{citation|first = Desa|last = Philadelphia|publisher = [[Time magazine|Time]]|title = Republican Convention: The Family Tree|date = August 7, 2000|url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,997685,00.html}}{{citation|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Wty3o92hyigC&pg=PR16#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = American Dynasty: Aristocracy, Fortune, and the Politics of Deceit in the House of Bush|authorlink = Kevin Phillips (political commentator)|first = Kevin|last = Phillips|publisher = [[Penguin Books]]|chapter = The Bush–Walker Family Tree|year = 2004|isbn = 9780143034315}}{{citation|title = Ancestors of American presidents|first1 = Gary Boyd|last1 = Roberts|first2 = Julie Helen|last2 = Otto|authorlink1 = Gary Boyd Roberts|publisher = [[New England Historic Genealogical Society]] / C. Boyer, 3rd|year = 1995|isbn = 9780936124193}}{{citation|authorlink = Mila Rechcigl|first = Mila|last = Rechcigl|url = http://www.svu2000.org/issues/bush.htm|title = Czech Roots of President Bush|publisher = [[Czechoslovak Society of Arts and Sciences]]|place = [[Washington, D.C.]]|accessdate = June 11, 2012}}{{citation|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TyfZWl73MqYC&pg=PR13#v=onepage&q&f=false|title = The Bush Tragedy|chapter = The Bush Family Tree|authorlink = Jacob Weisberg|first = Jacob|last = Weisberg|publisher = [[Random House]]|year = 2008|isbn = 9780812978353}} ==Awards and honors== [[File:GWB Lombardi.png|thumb|President [[George W. Bush]] in 2006 during a White House ceremony.
Beside him is the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy]], which is given to the winning team of the [[Super Bowl]].
Bush's cousin [[Joe Ellis]] is a two-time Super Bowl winner as an executive with the [[Denver Broncos]].]] ===Sports=== *Two-time [[Super Bowl]] champion – Joe Ellis (as an executive with the [[Denver Broncos]]) *1986 [[Theodore Roosevelt Award]] – George H.W. Bush *2007 [[National Football Foundation Gold Medal winners|National Football Foundation Gold Medal]] – George H. W. Bush *[[World Golf Hall of Fame]] – George H. W. Bush (class of 2011) ===Politics/public service=== *Three-time [[Time Person of the Year]] **George H. W. Bush (1990) **George W. Bush (2000, 2004) *Two-time [[Silver Buffalo Award]] winners **George H. W. Bush (1990) **George W. Bush (2002) *Seven statues **George H.W. Bush – three ([[Houston, TX]], [[Rapid City, SD]], [[Washington, D.C.]][https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/art/resources/pdf/VP_Busts_108_lo_res.pdf VP Busts - Senate.gov]) **George W. Bush – three (Rapid City, SD, [[Hamilton, OH]], [[Fushe Kruje]], [[Albania]])https://www.reuters.com/article/us-albania-statue-bush/albanian-town-thanks-george-w-bush-with-statue-idUSTRE7655J520110706 **George H.W./George W. Bush (shared) – one ([[Dallas, TX]]) *1989: Jersey Street in [[College Station, TX]] renamed George Bush Drive in honor of George H.W. Bush *1997: [[George Bush International Airport]] named in honor of George H. W. Bush *2007: [[Ronald Reagan Freedom Award]] – George H. W. Bush *2010: [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] – George H. W. Bush *2013: Portion of [[U.S. Highway 75]] in Dallas, TX renamed George W. Bush Expressway ===Military=== *[[Purple Heart]] – George H. W. Bush *[[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Presidential Unit Citation]] – George H. W. Bush *[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] – George H. W. Bush *Three-time [[Air Medal]] recipient – George H. W. Bush *[[Order of the Bath|Honorary Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] – George H. W. Bush *[[Venerable Order of St John|Commander of the Order of St John]] – William H. T. Bushhttps://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/L-59148-888305 *[[USS George H.W. Bush]] commissioned in 2009 – George H.W. Bush *[[National Defense Service Medal]] – George W. Bush, George P. Bush *[[Joint Service Commendation Medal]] – George P. Bush ==Political offices held== [[file:Seal of the President of the United States.svg||thumb|The Bush family are among four American families (Adams, Harrison, and Roosevelt being the others) to have had multiple members serve as U.S. President.]] [[file:George P. Bush by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|[[George P. Bush]] represents the fourth generation of the Bush family to have held elected office after becoming [[Texas Land Commissioner]] in 2015]] ===President=== *George H. W. Bush (41st) – 1989–1993 *George W. Bush (43rd) – 2001–2009 ===Vice President=== *George H. W. Bush – 1981–1989 ===U.S. Congress=== *Prescott Bush (Senator from Connecticut) – 1952–1963 *George H. W. Bush (Representative from Texas) – 1967–1971 ===Governor=== *George W. Bush (Texas) – 1995–2000 *Jeb Bush (Florida) – 1999–2007 ===Other=== *'''George H. W. Bush''' **UN Ambassador (1971–1973) **RNC Chairman (1973–1974) **Ambassador to China (1974–1975) **CIA Director (1976–1977) *'''Jeb Bush''' **Florida Secretary of Commerce (1987–1989) *'''George P. Bush''' **Texas Land Commissioner (2015–present) ==See also== *[[List of Presidents of the United States]] *[[List of U.S. political families]] *[[Political families of the world]] {{-}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * ''American Dynasty: Aristocracy, Fortune, and the Politics of Deceit in the House of Bush'' (2004), [[Kevin Phillips (political commentator)|Kevin Phillips]]. {{ISBN|0-670-03264-6}} * ''The Bushes: Portrait of a Dynasty'', [[Peter Schweizer]] ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20031218082226/http://www.cnn.com/2000/ALLPOLITICS/stories/12/13/president.bush/ Victory restores Bush dynasty to Washington] from [[CNN]] *[http://www.sptimes.com/2003/01/10/Floridian/The_Bush_dynasty_part.shtml The Bush dynasty parties on] from the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' {{Bush family}} {{George H. W. Bush}} {{George W. revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=December 2014}} {{Globalize|date=December 2010}} }} [[File:Business hours, Baja Fresh, Germantown, Maryland, August 25, 2016.jpg|thumb]] '''Business hours''' are the hours during the day in which [[business]] is commonly conducted. Typical business hours vary widely by country. By observing common informal standards for business hours, workers may communicate with each other more easily and find a convenient divide between work life and home life.
In the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[United Kingdom]] and [[Australia]], the hours between 9 [[12-hour clock|am]] and 5 [[12-hour clock|pm]] (the traditional "[[9 to 5]]") are typically considered to be standard business hours, although in the United States this varies by region due to local tradition and the need to conduct business by telephone with people in other [[time zone]]s. For instance, business in [[Chicago]] is often conducted between 8 am and 4:30 pm, while in [[New York City]], business hours tend to be later—for instance, from 10 am to 6 pm. On Saturdays, businesses are usually open from 8 or 9 am to noon or 1 pm.
In Mexico, the standard business hours are from 7 [[12-hour clock|am]] to 2 [[12-hour clock|pm]] and 4 [[12-hour clock|pm]] to 6 [[12-hour clock|pm]].
In Finland, government agencies and other institutions follow the hours 8:00am to 4:15pm. Banks are usually open to 4:30pm. Common business is done from Monday to Friday, but major shops are usually open on Saturdays 9:00am – 6:00pm and on Sundays 12:00pm – 9:00pm, with exceptions.
Other countries have different business hour patterns. Many workers in warmer climates observe [[Siesta]] during the afternoon, between the hours of 2 pm and 5 pm, effecting a pause in business hours, and resuming business in the evenings. La Siesta is a [[Spanish language]] term, which literally translates as a short nap of 15–30 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|title=La Siesta|url=http://www.donquijote.org/culture/spain/society/customs/siesta|website=DonQuijote.Org|accessdate=17 November 2014|ref=2}}</ref>
Business hours usually occur on [[weekday]]s. However, the days of the week on which business is conducted also varies from region to region in the world.
==Non-traditional business hours== Many businesses and organizations have extended or unlimited business hours if their business takes place continuously. For example, [[hotel]]s, [[airport]]s, and [[hospital]]s are open 24 hours a day, and transactions can take place at any point in time, thus requiring staffing and management availability at all times. Recent communications technology such as [[smartphone]]s has also extended the working day.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/mobile-phones/9646349/Smartphones-and-tablets-add-two-hours-to-the-working-day.html</ref>
==Restrictions== In some jurisdictions, legislation or regulations may require businesses to limit their trading hours. For example, some Western countries prohibit certain businesses from trading on Sundays, this being traditionally considered a day of rest. Businesses which serve hot food or alcoholic drinks are also frequently restricted in their trading hours.
==United States== In the [[United States]], the U.S. Department of Labor has mandated that companies must pay overtime to individuals who work over 40 hours a week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wage and Hour Division (WHD)|url=http://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/whdfs22.htm|website=U.S. Department of Labor|accessdate=17 November 2014|ref=1}}</ref> Businesses often do not schedule their employees to work more than 40 hours per week because they want to avoid paying their employees overtime.
==Greece== In [[Greece]], business hours on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays are usually from 9 am to 3 pm, while on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays are usually from 9 am to 2 pm and after the siesta from 5.30 pm to 9 pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cityofathens.gr/episkeptes/praktikes-plirofories/ores-leitoyrgias/katastimata|website=Municipality of Athens|accessdate=8 November 2016|ref=5}}</ref> Large stores and supermarkets follow an extended business hours schedule and are open Monday to Friday from 9 am to 9 pm and on Saturdays from 9 am to 8 pm. All stores are normally closed on Sundays, but there are several exceptions throughout the year. Banking and civil services hours are usually Monday to Friday from 8 am to 2 pm,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alphabank.com.cy/useful9.shtm|website=Alpha Bank|accessdate=8 November 2016|ref=6}}</ref> with minor variations but are always closed at weekends. All stores and offices are closed on public holidays.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Business hours}} [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Working time]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses|The Business School (disambiguation){{!}}The Business School}} A '''business school''' is a university-level institution that confers degrees in [[business administration]] or [[management]]. According to [[Andreas Kaplan|Kaplan]] business schools are "educational institutions that specialize in teaching courses and programs related to business and/or management".<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Andreas Kaplan: A school is "a building that has four walls…with tomorrow inside": Toward the reinvention of the business school | doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2018.03.010 | journal=Business Horizons}}</ref> Such a school can also be known as '''school of management''', '''school of business administration''', or colloquially '''b-school''' or '''biz school'''. A business school teaches topics such as [[accounting]], [[administration (business)|administration]], [[business strategy|strategy]], [[economics]], [[entrepreneurship]], [[finance]], [[human resource management]], [[management science]], [[management information systems]], [[international business]], [[logistics]], [[marketing]], [[organizational psychology]], [[organizational behavior]], [[public relations]], [[research methods]] and [[real estate]] among others.
==Types== There are several forms of business schools, including a school of business, business administration, and management. # Most of the university business schools consist of faculties, colleges, or departments within the university, and predominantly teach business courses (e.g. [[Mannheim Business School]]). # In [[North America]], a business school is often understood to be a university program that offers a graduate [[Master of Business Administration]] degrees and/or undergraduate bachelor's degrees (e.g. [[Harvard Business School]]). # In Europe and Asia, some universities teach predominantly business courses (e.g. [[Copenhagen Business School]]). # Privately owned business school which is not affiliated with any university (e.g. [[WHU-Otto Beisheim School of Management]]).
[[Andreas Kaplan|Kaplan]] classifies business schools along four '''C'''orners:<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Andreas Kaplan: A school is "a building that has four walls…with tomorrow inside": Toward the reinvention of the business school | doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2018.03.010 | journal=Business Horizons}}</ref> # '''C'''ulture (Europe - US): Independent of their actual (physical) location, business schools can be classified according to whether they follow the European or the US model. # '''C'''ompass (international/global – regional/local): Business schools can be classified along a continuum, with international/ global schools on one end and regional/ local schools on the other. # '''C'''apital (public – private): Business schools can either be publicly (state) funded or privately funded, for example through endowments or tuition fees. # '''C'''ontent (teaching – research): Business school can be classified according to whether a school considers teaching or research to be its primary focus.
==Notable firsts== [[Image:Escp-Paris.jpg|thumb|220px|[[ESCP Europe]], France, founded in 1819]] [[Image:BGF 1.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Budapest Business School]], Hungary, the first public business school founded in 1857]] [[Image:Huntsman Hall at the University of Pennsylvania.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School]], US, founded in 1881]] [[Image:University of St. Gallen Convention and Executive Education Center.jpg|right|thumbnail|220px|[[University of St. Gallen]], Switzerland, founded in 1898]] [[File:HEC carré Viger 1907.jpg|alt=First building of HEC Montréal in Montreal|thumb|Founded in 1907, [[HEC Montréal]] is the oldest School of Management in Canada.]] [[File:ESSEC campus Cergy.PNG|thumb|right|[[ESSEC]] in [[France]] and [[Singapore]] was the first business school being [[AACSB]] accredited outside North America in 1997]] [[Image:Haas_School_of_Business_.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Haas School of Business]], US, founded in 1898]] * 1759 – The Aula do Comércio in [[Lisbon]] was the first institution to specialise in the teaching of accounting in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otoc.pt/fotos/editor2/Aula_do_Comercio%20-%20L%C3%BAcia%20Lima%20Rodrigues.pdf|title=Aula do Comércio (1759-1844): Primeiro Estabelecimento Governamental de Ensino de Contabilidade|last=Rodrigues|first=Lúcia Lima|language=portuguese|accessdate=9 April 2012|publisher=Ordem dos Técnicos Oficiais de Contas}}</ref> It provided a model for development of similar government-sponsored schools across Europe, and closed in 1844.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otoc.pt/fotos/editor2/Aula_do_Comercio%20-%20L%C3%BAcia%20Lima%20Rodrigues.pdf|title=Aula do Comércio (1759-1844): Primeiro Estabelecimento Governamental de Ensino de Contabilidade|last=Rodrigues|first=Lúcia Lima|language=portuguese|accessdate=9 April 2012|publisher=Ordem dos Técnicos Oficiais de Contas}}</ref> Therefore, the Aula do Comércio paved the way for business schools to start.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalgraduate.net/articles/business-schools-business-programs.htm|title=Business Schools and business programs - Graduate International}}</ref> * 1819 – The world's first business school, [[Ecole Supérieure de Commerce de Paris|ESCP Europe]] was in [[Paris]], [[France]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Andreas Kaplan: European Management and European Business Schools: Insights from the History of Business Schools | doi=10.1016/j.emj.2014.03.006 | volume=32 | journal=European Management Journal | pages=529–534}}</ref> It is the oldest business school in the world<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.generation-europe.eu/assets/resources/youth_centre/career_development_and_employment/career_guidance/FocusOn2012-09Career-GuidanceUK.pdf |title=Focus On - Generation Europe Foundation - Career Guidance (page 5) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517222047/http://www.generation-europe.eu/assets/resources/youth_centre/career_development_and_employment/career_guidance/FocusOn2012-09Career-GuidanceUK.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalgraduate.net/articles/business-schools-business-programs.htm|title=Business Schools and business programs - Graduate International}}</ref> and now has campuses in [[Berlin]], [[London]], [[Madrid]], [[Paris]], [[Torino]], and [[Warsaw]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ESCP EUROPE - Torino|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/escp-europe-torino/postgrad|website=TopUniversities|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.escpeurope.eu/campus/warsaw/contact-and-location-escp-europe-london-campus/ Warsaw Campus - escpeurope.eu]</ref> * 1855 – The Institut Supérieur de Commerce d'Anvers (State funded) and the Institut Saint-Ignace – École Spéciale de Commerce et d'Industrie (Jesuits education) were founded in the same year in the city of [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Mansoor Iqbal|title=The 10 Top European Business Schools According to International Recruiters|url=http://www.topmba.com/mba-programs/10-top-european-business-schools-according-international-recruiters|website=TopMBA|accessdate=9 November 2015|date=2 December 2015}}</ref> After getting university status in 1965 and after almost 150 years of business education and rivalry between each other, both merged in 2003 into what became the [[University of Antwerp]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The University of Antwerp, Belgium|url=http://www.thecompleteuniversityguide.co.uk/international/europe/belgium/the-university-of-antwerp/|website=TheCompleteUniversity|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> * 1857 – The world's first public business school, [[Budapest Business School]] was founded in [[Budapest]] in [[Austria-Hungary]] as the first business school in [[Central Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.bgf.hu/About-Us/history|title=BBS History}}</ref> * 1868 – The [[Ca' Foscari University]] was founded in [[Venice]]. It is the oldest business school in [[Italy]] and one of the oldest in the world. * 1871 – The [[Rouen Business School]] which has merged with [[Reims Management School]] under the name of [[NEOMA Business School]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ginibrière|first1=Gaëlle|title=Business Schools: Rouen and Reims unite to view larger|url=http://etudiant.lefigaro.fr/orientation/actus-et-conseils/detail/article/ecoles-de-commerce-rouen-et-reims-s-unissent-pour-jouer-en-coupe-d-europe-1868/|website=Lefigaro|accessdate=9 November 2015|language=French|date=14 May 2013}}</ref> [[Rouen Business School]] is the second oldest French business school. * 1871 – The ESC Le Havre was created (now [[École de management de Normandie]]). Created the same year than [[Rouen Business School]] it is also the second oldest French business school. * 1881 – The [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] is the United States' first business school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wharton.upenn.edu/about/wharton-history.cfm |title=Wharton History |publisher=The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|date=|accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> [[HEC Paris]] (The École des Hautes Études Commerciales de Paris) was established by the Paris Chamber of Commerce (CCIP). * 1892 – The [[ESC Lille]] in northern France which has mergered with CERAM Business School (created in 1963) under the name of [[Skema Business School]] since 2009. * 1898 – On the west coast [[Haas School of Business]] is established as the College of Commerce of the [[University of California]] with Carl Copping Plehn as the Dean in 1898 and became the first [[public]] business school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haas.berkeley.edu/haas/about.html|title=Haas School of Business|accessdate = 4 March 2016|publisher=Haas School of Business}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/haas/about/centennial.html|title=History of Haas|accessdate = 4 March 2016|publisher=Haas School of Business}}</ref> The [[Booth School of Business]] The University of Chicago Booth School of Business also traces its beginnings to 1898 when university faculty member James Laurence Laughlin chartered the College of Commerce and Politics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobooth.edu/about/facts|title=Chicago Booth School of Business|accessdate=2 Dec 2014|publisher=Chicago Booth School of Business}}</ref> * 1898 – [[Handelshochschule Leipzig]], today [[Leipzig Graduate School of Management]], was founded as the first Business School in [[Germany]], so it is the oldest university teaching economics in German speaking regions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hhl.de/en/home/|title=HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management}}</ref> * 1898 – The [[University of St. Gallen]] established the first university in [[Switzerland]] teaching business and economics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wirtschaftslexikon.gabler.de/Definition/betriebswirtschaftslehre-bwl.html?tab=erklaerung|title=Definition: Betriebswirtschaftlehre (BWL)|language=German|accessdate=10 June 2012|publisher=Gabler Wirtschaftslexikon}}</ref> * 1900 – The first [[graduate school]] of business in the United States, the [[Tuck School of Business]] at [[Dartmouth College]], was founded.<ref>[http://www.tuck.dartmouth.edu/about/history/ Tuck School of Business | History]. Tuck.dartmouth.edu. Retrieved on 2013-07-26.</ref> The school conferred the first [[advanced degree]] in business, specifically, a [[Master of Science]] in Commercial Sciences, the predecessor to the MBA. * 1902 – The [[Birmingham Business School (University of Birmingham)|Birmingham Business School]] of [[University of Birmingham]] is the United Kingdom's first business school. Established as the School of Commerce in [[Birmingham]], [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/postgraduate/business-schools/birmingham-business-school-1206244.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Birmingham Business School | date=2010-12-12}}</ref> * 1903 – The [[Solvay Brussels School of Economics and Management]] of [[Université Libre de Bruxelles]] is the Belgium's first business school created by an entrepreneur Ernest Solvay, founder of the chemistry company Solvay. * 1906 – The Department of Commerce was founded as part of [[McGill University]] in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], [[Canada]], eventually developing into the [[Desautels Faculty of Management]].<ref>[https://www.mcgill.ca/desautels/about/history History | Desautels]. mcgill.ca</ref> * 1906 – The [[Warsaw School of Economics]] (SGH) was established as the first university in [[Poland]] dedicated to teaching commerce and economics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sgh.waw.pl/en/ogolne-en/history/|title=History of the School|accessdate=8 August 2012|publisher=SGH}}</ref> * 1907 – [[HEC Montréal]] is founded in [[Montreal]], being the first School of Management of its kind in Canada. It was also the first school in North America to be awarded the 3 most prestigious accreditations (AACSB, AMBA, EQUIS), which less than 70 schools in the world have achieved. * 1907 – [[ESSEC|ESSEC Business School]] in [[Paris]], which was later the first Business School outside [[North America]] to be accredited by the [[AACSB]] (main and most famous association to accredit schools of business) in 1997 * 1908 – [[Kellogg School of Management]] was founded as [[Northwestern University]]'s School of Commerce.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/kellogg_school_history/1908-1917.aspx|title=1908-1917 {{!}} Kellogg School of Management {{!}} Northwestern University|website=www.kellogg.northwestern.edu|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> * 1908 – [[Harvard Business School]] was founded at Harvard University. It was the first program in the world to offer the Master of Business Administration degree.<ref>{{cite journal |title=History of the MBA MBA Friday Facts|url=http://www.topmba.com/why-mba/history-mba-mba-friday-facts|journal=www.topmba.com}}</ref> * 1909 – [[Stockholm School of Economics]] was founded on the initiative of the Swedish business sector and is the oldest business school in Sweden.<ref>{{cite journal|title=European Management and European Business Schools: Insights from the History of Business Schools|journal=European Management Journal|date=2014|first=Andreas M|last=Kaplan|doi=10.1016/j.emj.2014.03.006|volume=32|pages=529–534}}</ref> [[Hanken School of Economics]] was established the same year in Helsinki, Finland.<ref>{{cite web|title=HANKEN Swedish School of Economics and Business Administration|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/top/hanken.html|website=Helsinki|accessdate=9 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122004358/http://www.helsinki.fi/top/hanken.html|archivedate=22 November 2015|df=}}</ref> * 1914 – MIT Sloan School of Management was founded in MIT (as Course XV - Engineering Administration)<ref>http://mitsloan.mit.edu/about-mit-sloan/history/</ref> * 1919 – [[Babson College]] was the first business school founded to focus solely on entrepreneurship. Every graduate receives a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration. * 1920 – [[Kelley School of Business]] was founded as [[Indiana University-Bloomington]]'s School of Commerce and Finance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelley School of Business History|url=http://bulletins.iu.edu/iub/kelley-ugrad/2011-2012/overview/history.shtml}}</ref> * 1922 – First doctoral program in business was offered at [[The University of Chicago]] [[Booth School of Business]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobooth.edu/about/history|title=Chicago Booth History|accessdate=19 Jan 2017|publisher=Chicago Booth School of Business}}</ref> * 1936 – The [[Norwegian School of Economics]] (also known as NHH) is the oldest business school in Norway.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhh.no/en/about-nhh/nhh-history/development-of-nhh.aspx |title=The growth and development of NHH |publisher=www.nhh.no |accessdate=2014-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812183619/http://www.nhh.no/en/about-nhh/nhh-history/development-of-nhh.aspx |archivedate=2014-08-12 |df= }}</ref> * 1946 – The [[Thunderbird School of Global Management]], then called the American Institute for Foreign Trade, was the first graduate management school focused exclusively on global business.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://phoenix.bizjournals.com/phoenix/stories/2007/02/05/daily6.html |title=Thunderbird school changes name as it seizes new opportunities – Phoenix Business Journal |publisher=Phoenix.bizjournals.com |date=2007-02-05 |accessdate=2012-03-22 |first=Angela |last=Gonzales}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thunderbird.edu/about_thunderbird/news/media_relations/news_releases/2008/_06_17_thunderbird_history.htm |title=Thunderbird history showcased through Arizona Memory Project – Thunderbird School of Global Management |publisher=Thunderbird.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> * 1949 – The [[University of Pretoria]] in South Africa founded the oldest business school in Africa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mba.co.za/school.aspx?rootid=7&schoolid=25&pageid=additional |title=Wits Business School |publisher=MBA.co.za |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809003621/http://www.mba.co.za/school.aspx?rootid=7&schoolid=25&pageid=additional |archivedate=2007-08-09 |df= }}</ref> In January 2008 the Graduate School of Management was formally replaced by the [[Gordon Institute of Business Science]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Gordon Institute of Business Science|url=https://www.gibs.co.za/|website=GIBS|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> *1949 – [[XLRI]] – India's oldest business management school is founded.<ref>[[XLRI- Xavier School of Management]]</ref> * 1953 – [[IISWBM]] is the first institute in India to offer an MBA degree.<ref>[[Indian Institute of Social Welfare and Business Management]]</ref> * 1954 – The [[Faculty of Management Studies (Delhi)|Faculty of Management Studies]] (FMS), University of Delhi is among one of the oldest business schools in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fms.edu/?q=node/10|title=History - Faculty of Management Studies|work=fms.edu}}</ref> * 1955 – The [[Institute of Business Administration, Karachi]] was the first business school to be established outside North America to offer an MBA degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iba.edu.pk/historyofiba.php|title=Institute of Business Administration - Karachi|work=iba.edu.pk}}</ref> * 1963 – [[ESAN University]] Graduate School of Business in [[Lima]], [[Peru]] was the first Graduate Business School founded in [[Latin America]]. It was established under an agreement between the Government of the [[United States Of America]], [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] and the Government of [[Peru]]. * 1991 – The [[IEDC-Bled School of Management]] was the first business school to offer an MBA program in [[Eastern Europe]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/postgraduate/business-schools/iedc-ndash-bled-school-of-management-1206315.html | work=The Independent | title=IEDC – Bled School of Management | date=2010-12-21 | location=London}}</ref> * 1994 – CEIBS ([[China Europe International Business School]]) was the first business school in China to have received funding from a foreign government, namely the European Commission.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessbecause.com/mba-life/charmed-by-china.htm |title=Charmed by China |publisher=Business Because |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726151613/http://www.businessbecause.com/mba-life/charmed-by-china.htm |archivedate=2011-07-26 |df= }}</ref> * 2001 – ISB ([[Indian School of Business|Indian School of business]]) is a private business school with campuses in two states of India, one in Hyderabad, Telangana and one in Mohali, Punjab. * 2015 – The [[Daniels College of Business]] was the first business school to launch a challenge-driven MBA program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mba.du.edu |title=The Denver MBA}}</ref>
==Degrees== Common degrees are as follows. * [[Associate's degree]]: AA, AAB, ABA, AS * [[Bachelor's Degree]]s: [[Bachelor of Commerce|BCom]], [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Bachelor of Science|BS]], BBA ([[Bachelor of Business Administration]]), BBus ([[Bachelor of Business]]), [[Bachelor of Business Administration|BSBA]], [[Bachelor of Accountancy|BAcc]], BABA, BBS, BMOS and BBusSc ([[Bachelor of Business Science]]) * [[Master's Degree]]s: [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]], [[Masters in Business and Management (MBM)|MBM]], [[Master of Management]], [[Master of Accountancy|MAcc]], [[Master of Marketing Research|MMR]], [[Master of Marketing Research|MSMR]], [[Master of Accountancy|MPA]], [[Master of Information Systems Management|MISM]], [[Master of Science in Management|MSM]], [[Master of Health Administration|MHA]], [[Master of Science in Finance|MSF]], [[MSc]], [[Master of Science in Taxation|MST]], [[Masters in Management Studies|MMS]], EMBA and [[Master of Commerce|MCom]]. At Oxford and Cambridge business schools an [[MPhil]] or [[MSc]], is awarded in place of an MA. * [[Doctorate|Doctoral Degrees]]: [[Ph.D.]], [[Doctor of Business Administration|DBA]], [[Doctor of Health Administration|DHA]], [[Doctor of Management|DM]], Doctor of Commerce (DCOM), [[PhD in Management]] or Business Doctorate (Doctor of Philosophy), Doctor of Professional Studies (DPS)
==Use of case studies== Some business schools structure their teaching around the use of case studies (i.e. the [[case method]]). Case studies have been used in Graduate and Undergraduate business education for nearly one hundred years. Business cases are historical descriptions of actual business situations. Typically, information is presented about a business firm's products, markets, competition, financial structure, sales volumes, management, employees and other factors influencing the firm's success. The length of a business case study may range from two or three pages to 30 pages, or more.
Business schools often obtain case studies published by the [[Harvard Business Publishing|Harvard Business School]], [[INSEAD]], [[London Business School]], the [[Kellogg School of Management]] at [[Northwestern University]], the [[Ross School of Business]] at the [[University of Michigan]], the [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] at [[The University of Western Ontario]], the [[Darden School]] at the [[University of Virginia]], [[IESE]], other academic institutions, or case clearing houses (such as The Case Centre). Harvard's most popular case studies include ''[[Lincoln Electric]] Co.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/b01/en/common/item_detail.jhtml?id=376028 |title=Lincoln Electric Co |publisher=Harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> and ''[[Google]], Inc.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/b01/en/common/item_detail.jhtml?id=806105 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120711040437/http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/b01/en/common/item_detail.jhtml?id=806105 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-11 |title=Google Inc |publisher=Harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22 }}</ref>
Students are expected to scrutinize the case study and prepare to discuss strategies and tactics that the firm should employ in the future. Three different methods have been used in business case teaching: # Preparing case-specific questions to be answered by the student. This is used with short cases intended for Undergraduate students. The underlying concept is that such students need specific guidance to be able to analyze case studies. # Problem-solving analysis is the second method initiated by the [[Harvard Business School]] which is by far the most widely used method in MBA and executive development programs. The underlying concept is that with enough practice (hundreds of case analyses) students develop intuitive skills for analyzing and resolving complex business situations. Successful implementation of this method depends heavily on the skills of the discussion leader. # A generally applicable [[strategic planning]] approach. This third method does not require students to analyze hundreds of cases. A strategic planning model is provided and students are instructed to apply the steps of the model to six – and up to a dozen cases – during a semester. This is sufficient to develop their ability to analyze a complex situation, generate a variety of possible strategies and to select the best ones. In effect, students learn a generally applicable approach to analyze cases studies and real situations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mbatoolbox.org/stories/storyReader$19 |title=Chapter 1.2. A Model for Strategic Planning, Analyzing Cases and Decision Making |publisher=Mbatoolbox.org |date=2006-02-22 |accessdate=2012-03-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204141117/http://www.mbatoolbox.org/stories/storyReader$19 |archive-date=2012-02-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> This approach does not make any extraordinary demands on the artistic and dramatic talents of the teacher. Consequently, most professors are capable of supervising the application of this method.
===History of business cases=== When [[Harvard Business School]] started operating in 1908, the faculty realized that there were no textbooks suitable for a graduate program in business.<ref>{{cite web|last1= Yumlembam|first1= Dayananda|title= MICA innovation to help Harvard business school sharpen teaching tools|url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/MICA-innovation-to-help-Harvard-business-school-sharpen-teaching-tools/articleshow/9351342.cms |website= Times of India|publisher= TNN|accessdate= 9 November 2015 |quote = When Harvard Business School was started, its faculty members realized that there were no textbooks suitable to a graduate program in business. That was when they decided to use case studies which are detailed accounts of innovative methods and practices that managers follow. }} </ref> Their first solution to this problem involved interviewing leading practitioners of business and writing detailed accounts of what these managers were doing, based partly on the case method already in use at [[Harvard Law School]]. Of course, the professors could not present these [[case (disambiguation)|case]]s as practices to be emulated, because there were no criteria available for determining what would succeed and what would not succeed. So the professors instructed their students to read the cases and to come to class prepared to discuss the cases and to offer recommendations for appropriate courses of action. The basic outlines of this method still operate in business-school curricula {{as of | 2016 | lc = on}}.
==Other approaches== In contrast to the case method some schools use a skills-based approach in teaching business. This approach emphasizes quantitative methods, in particular [[operations research]], [[management information systems]], [[statistics]], organizational behavior, [[Scientific modelling|modeling]] and [[simulation]], and [[decision science]]. The leading institution in this method is the [[Tepper School of Business]] at [[Carnegie Mellon University]]. The goal is to provide students a set of tools that will prepare them to tackle and solve problems.
Another important approach used in business school is the use of [[business game]]s that are used in different disciplines such as business, economics, management, etc. Some colleges are blending many of these approaches throughout their degree programs, and even blending the method of delivery for each of these approaches. A study from by Inside Higher Ed and the Babson Survey Research Group<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kolowich|first1=Steve|title=Online Learning and Liberal Arts Colleges|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/06/29/liberal-arts-college-explore-uses-blended-online-learning|website=Inside Highered|accessdate=9 November 2015|date=29 June 2012}}</ref> shows that there is still disagreement as to the effectiveness of the approaches but the reach and accessibility is proving to be more and more appealing. [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States]] like [[New England College]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bisk.com/pr/new-england-college-launches-online-degrees|title=Bisk Education|work=bisk.com}}</ref> [[Wesleyan University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/06/29/liberal-arts-college-explore-uses-blended-online-learning|title=Liberal arts college explore uses of 'blended' online learning - InsideHigherEd.com|work=insidehighered.com}}</ref> and [[Bryn Mawr College]] are now offering complete [[online degrees]] in many business curriculae despite the controversy that surrounds the learning method.
There are also several business schools which still rely on the lecture method to give students a basic business education. Lectures are generally given from the professor's point of view, and rarely require interaction from the students unless notetaking is required. Lecture as a method of teaching in business schools has been criticized by experts for reducing the incentive and individualism in the learning experience.<ref>{{cite journal|url= https://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/files/?whdmsaction=public:main.file&fileID=8113 | title = Natural Learning in Higher Education| author = J. Scott Armstrong | journal = Encyclopedia of the Sciences of Learning | year = 2012}}</ref>
==Executive education== In addition to teaching students, many business schools run Executive Education programs. These may be either open programs or company-specific programs. Executives may also acquire an MBA title in an Executive MBA program within university of business or from top ranked business schools. Many business schools seek close co-operation with business.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schreuder, Hein|first1=Jeannet, Jean-Pierre|title=From Coal to Biotech The Transformation of DSM with Business School Support |isbn=9783662462997 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/From_Coal_to_Biotech.html?id=0gdJCAAAQBAJ |accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>
==Accreditation==
There are three main accreditation agencies for business schools in the United States: [[ACBSP]], [[AACSB]], and the [[IACBE]]. In [[Europe]], the [[EQUIS]] accreditation system is run by the [[EFMD]] and [[Association of MBAs|AMBA]].
==Global Master of Business Administration ranking== Each year, well-known business publications such as ''The Economist'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Which MBA?|url=http://www.economist.com/whichmba|website=Economist|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> ''Eduniversal'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Eduniversal Rating: Palmes Of Excellence|url=http://www.eduniversal-ranking.com/methodology/palms|website=Eduniversal Ranking|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> ''U.S. News & World Report'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/spec-business |title=Best Undergraduate Business Programs | Rankings | US News |publisher=Colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826121834/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/spec-business |archivedate=2009-08-26 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-business-schools/mba-rankings |title=Best Business School Rankings | MBA Program Rankings | US News |publisher=Grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date=2012-03-13 |accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> ''Fortune'', ''Financial Times'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/global-mba-rankings |title=Business school rankings from the Financial Times - Global MBA Rankings 2012 |publisher=Rankings.ft.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> ''Business Week'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/bschools |title=Business Schools |publisher=Businessweek |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> ''Expansion''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expansi%C3%B3n_(Mexico) |title=Expansion Mexico-MBA Rankings in Mexico and the World |publisher=expansion.mx |date= |accessdate=2016-03-12}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=June 2018}} and ''The Wall Street Journal''<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/public/page/business-schools.html |title=Business Schools - MBA Rankings and Executive Education Programs - Wsj.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116173129/http://wsj.com/public/page/business-schools.html |archive-date=2014-01-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> publish rankings of selected MBA programs and business schools that, while controversial in their methodology,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.bestmatchforyou.com/best_business_school_to_best_mba_fit_for_you/ |title=From Best Business School to Best MBA Fit for You |publisher=Best Match |date= |accessdate=2014-05-01}}</ref> nevertheless can directly influence the prestige of schools that achieve high scores. Academic research is also considered to be an important feature and popular way to gauge the prestige of business schools.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://qbox.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/MKTG/research/Learning%20vs%20Teaching.pdf | title = Learning versus Teaching: Reply to Commentaries | author = J. Scott Armstrong | journal = Interfaces | volume = 24 | pages = 39–43 | year = 1994 | access-date = 2012-02-06 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120727134053/http://qbox.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/MKTG/research/Learning%20vs%20Teaching.pdf | archive-date = 2012-07-27 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| url = http://qbox.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/mktg/research/Business%20School%20Prestige.pdf| title = Business School Prestige – Research versus Teaching| journal = Journal of Marketing| volume = 59| publisher = American Marketing Association| pages = 101–106| year = 1995}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/ideas/pdf/armstrong2/devil.pdf | title = Book Reviewed: Peter Robinson, Snapshots from Hell, New York: Warner Books, 1994. | author = J. Scott Armstrong and Tad Sperry | journal = Interfaces | volume = 24 | pages = 13–43 | year = 1994 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100620185501/http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/ideas/pdf/armstrong2/devil.pdf | archivedate = 2010-06-20 | df = }}</ref> Business schools share the common purpose of developing global managerial talent and to this end, business schools are encouraged to accelerate global engagement strategies on the foundations of collaboration and innovation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aacsb.edu/blog/2017/september/accelerating-global-engagement-with-collaboration-and-innovation|title=Accelerating Global Engagement With Collaboration and Innovation|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|date=September 19, 2017|website=AACSB International|access-date=}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Lists of business schools}}Lists== <!-- This section is linked from [[Lists of universities and colleges]] --> * [[Ivy League business schools|List of Ivy League business schools]] * [[Big Ten business schools|List of Big Ten business schools]] * [[List of business schools in Africa]] * [[List of business schools in Australia]] * [[List of business schools in Asia]] * [[List of business schools in Canada]] * [[List of business schools in Chile]] * [[List of business schools in Europe]] * [[:Category:Business schools in France|List of business schools in France]] * [[:Category:Business schools in Germany|List of business schools in Germany]] * [[List of business schools in India]] * [[List of business schools in South Africa]] * [[List of business schools in Switzerland]] * [[List of business schools in New Zealand]] * [[List of business schools in the United States]] * [[List of United States graduate business school rankings]]
