{{Refimprove|date=December 2008}} [[File:FMIB 33966 Removing Blubber from Whale Beached on California Coast.jpeg|thumb|Rendering a beached whale in California]] '''Rendering''' is a process that converts waste animal [[biological tissue|tissue]] into stable, usable materials. Rendering can refer to any processing of [[animal product]]s into more useful materials, or, more narrowly, to the rendering of whole animal fatty tissue into purified fats like [[lard]] or [[tallow]]. Rendering can be carried out on an industrial, farm, or kitchen [[Scalability|scale]].
The majority of tissue processed comes from [[slaughterhouse]]s, but also includes restaurant grease and butcher shop trimmings and expired meat from grocery stores. This material can include the [[fat]]ty tissue, bones, and [[offal]], as well as entire carcasses of animals condemned at slaughterhouses, and those that have died on farms, in transit, etc. The most common animal sources are [[beef]], [[pork]], [[sheep]], and [[poultry]].
The rendering process simultaneously dries the material and separates the fat from the [[bone]] and [[protein]]. A rendering process yields a fat [[commodity]] ([[yellow grease]], choice white grease, bleachable fancy [[tallow]], etc.) and a protein meal ([[meat and bone meal]], poultry byproduct meal, etc.).
Rendering plants often also handle other materials, such as slaughterhouse [[blood]], [[feather]]s and [[hair]], but do so using processes distinct from true rendering.
The occupation of renderer has appeared in "dirtiest jobs" lists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/dirtiest-jobs/story?id=17130057#2 |title=The Seven Dirtiest Jobs |website=ABC News |date=Sep 3, 2012 |accessdate=29 January 2014 |author=Ellin, Abby}}</ref>
==Process variations== The rendering process varies in a number of ways: * Whether the end products are used as human or animal food depends on the quality of input material and the processing methods and equipment. * The material may be processed by wet or dry means. In wet processing, either boiling water or steam is added to the material, separating fat into a floating phase. In dry processing, fat is released by dehydrating the raw material. * The temperature range used may be high or low. * Rendering may be done either in discrete batches or in a continuous process. * The processing plant may be operated by an independent company that buys input material from suppliers, or by a packing plant that produces the material in-house.
==Rendering processes for edible products== Edible rendering processes are basically meat processing operations and produce [[lard]] or edible [[tallow]] for use in food products. Edible rendering is generally carried out in a continuous process at low temperature (less than the boiling point of water). The process usually consists of finely chopping the edible fat materials (generally fat trimmings from meat cuts), heating them with or without added steam, and then carrying out two or more stages of [[centrifugal separation]]. The first stage separates the liquid water and fat mixture from the solids. The second stage further separates the fat from the water. The solids may be used in food products, pet foods, etc., depending on the original materials. The separated fat may be used in food products, or if in surplus, may be diverted to soap making operations. Most edible rendering is done by meat packing or processing companies.
One edible product is [[Greaves (food)|greaves]], which is the unmeltable residue left after animal fat has been rendered.
An alternative process cooks slaughterhouse [[offal]] to produce a thick, lumpy "stew" for the pet food industry, which uses it principally in tinned [[Cat food|cat]] and [[dog food]]s. Such plants are notable for the offensive odour that they can produce, and are often located well away from human habitation.
==Rendering processes for inedible products== Materials that for aesthetic or sanitary reasons are not suitable for human food are the feedstocks for inedible rendering processes. Much of the inedible raw material is rendered using the "dry" method. This may be a batch or a continuous process in which the material is heated in a steam-jacketed vessel to drive off the moisture and simultaneously release the fat from the fat cells. The material is first ground, then heated to release the fat and drive off the moisture, percolated to drain off the free fat, and then more fat is pressed out of the solids, which at this stage are called "cracklings" or "dry-rendered tankage". The cracklings are further ground to make meat and [[bone meal]].
A variation on a dry process involves finely chopping the material, fluidizing it with hot fat, and then evaporating the mixture in one or more evaporator stages. Some inedible rendering is done using a wet process, which is generally a continuous process similar in some ways to that used for edible materials. The material is heated with added steam and then pressed to remove a water-fat mixture that is then separated into fat, water, and fine solids by stages of centrifuging and/or evaporation. The solids from the press are dried and then ground into meat and bone meal. Most independent renderers process only inedible material.
==History== The development of rendering was primarily responsible for the profitable utilization of meat industry by-products, which in turn allowed the development of a massive industrial-scale meat industry that made food more economical for the consumer. Rendering has been carried out for many centuries, primarily for [[soap]] and [[candle]] making. The earliest rendering was done in a [[kettle]] over an open fire. This type of rendering is still done on farms to make lard (pork fat) for food purposes. With the development of steam boilers, it was possible to use steam-jacketed kettles to make a higher grade product, and reduce fire danger. A further development came in the 19th century with the use of steam digesters: a tank used as a pressure cooker where steam was injected into the material being rendered. This process is a wet rendering process called "tanking" and was used for edible and inedible products, although better grades of edible products were made using the open kettle process. After the material is tanked, the free fat is run off, the remaining water ("tank water") run into a separate vat, and the solids removed and dried by pressing and steam-drying in a jacketed vessel. The tank water was either run into a [[sanitary sewer|sewer]] or it was evaporated to make [[glue]] or protein concentrate to add to [[fertilizer]]. The solids were used for fertilizer.
[[Upton Sinclair]] wrote ''[[The Jungle]]'' (1906), an exposé on the Chicago meat processing industry which created public outrage. His work helped the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1907 which paved the way for the creation of the [[FDA]].
The pressure tank made possible the development of the [[Chicago]] meat industry in the United States, with its concentration in one geographic area, because it allowed the economic disposal of byproducts which would otherwise overwhelm the environment in that area. At first, small companies that sprang up near the packers did the rendering. Later the packers entered the rendering industry. [[Gustavus Swift]], [[Nelson Morris]], and [[Lucius Darling]] were among the early pioneers of the U.S. rendering industry with their personal backing and/or direct participation in the rendering industry.
Innovations came rapidly in the 20th century. Some of these were the uses for rendered products, and others were the rendering methods. In the 1920s, a batch dry rendering process was invented; the material was cooked in horizontal steam-jacketed cylinders (similar to the fertilizer dryers of the day). Advantages claimed for the dry process were economy of energy, better protein yield, faster processing, and fewer obnoxious odors. Over the years, the wet "tanking" process was replaced with the dry process. By the end of [[World War II]], most rendering installations used the dry process. In the 1960s, continuous dry processes were introduced, one using a variation of the conventional dry cooker and the other making use of a mincing and evaporation process to dry the material and yield the fat. In the 1980s, high energy costs popularized the various "wet" continuous processes. These processes were more energy efficient and allowed the re-use of process vapours to pre-heat or dry the materials during the process.
After [[WWII]], synthetic detergents arrived, which displaced soaps in domestic and industrial washing. In the early 1950s, over half of the inedible fat market vanished. Diversion in these materials into animal feeds soon replaced the lost soap market and eventually became the single largest use for inedible fats.
The widespread use of "boxed beef", where the beef was cut into consumer portions at packing plants rather than local butcher shops and markets, meant that fat and meat scraps for renderers stayed at the packing plants and were rendered there by packer renderers, rather than by the independent rendering companies.
The rejection of animal fats by diet-conscious consumers led to a surplus of edible fats, and the resultant diversion into soapmaking and [[oleochemical]]s, displacing inedible fats and contributing to the market volatility of this commodity.
==Advantages and disadvantages== The rendering industry is one of the oldest recycling industries, and made possible the development of a large food industry. The industry takes what would otherwise be waste materials and makes useful products such as fuels, soaps, rubber, plastics, etc. At the same time, rendering solves what would otherwise be a major disposal problem. As an example, the USA recycles more than 21 million metric tons annually of highly perishable and noxious organic matter. In 2004, the U.S. industry produced over 8 million metric tons of products, of which 1.6 million metric tons were exported.
Usually, materials used as raw materials in the rendering process are susceptible to spoilage. However, after rendering, the materials are much more resistant to spoiling. This is due to the application of heat either through cooking in the wet rendering process or the extraction of fluid in the dry rendering process. The fat obtained can be used as low-cost raw material in making grease, animal feed, soap, candles, [[biodiesel]], and as a feed-stock for the [[chemical]] industry. [[Tallow]], derived from beef waste, is an important raw material in the [[steel]] rolling industry providing the required lubrication when compressing steel sheets.
Meat and bones (in a dry, ground state) are converted to ''[[meat and bone meal]]''. Health professionals believe that meat and bone meal in animal feed was the main route for the late-20th century spread of [[bovine spongiform encephalopathy]] (mad-cow disease, BSE), which is also fatal to human beings. Early in the 21st century, most countries tightened regulations to prevent this.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.usda.gov/wps/portal/usda/usdahome?contentid=BSE_FAQs.xml |title=FAQ on BSE |website=United States Department of Agriculture |access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref>
If not for the rendering industry, the cost of waste animal material would be high and would place a significant economic and environmental burden on areas involved in industrial scale slaughtering. This cost would manifest itself through the use of expensive sanitary landfills, incinerators, and other similar waste disposal techniques without yielding profit from [[opportunity costs]]. Alternatives to rendering products may not reduce cost.
==Kitchen rendering== Rendering of fats is also carried out on a kitchen scale by [[chef]]s and home cooks. In the kitchen, rendering is used to transform [[butter]] into [[clarified butter]], [[suet]] into [[tallow]], [[pork]] fat into [[lard]], and chicken fat into [[schmaltz]].
==See also== * [[Animal slaughter]] * [[Animal euthanasia]] * [[Dead Horse Bay]] * [[Flensing]] * [[Vegetable oil]] * [[Whale oil]]

Simon & Schuster, New York, 1998 * National Renderer's Association, Render Magazine, April 2005. * National Renderer's Association, North American Rendering—The Source of Essential High Quality Products. Burnham, Frank * Rendering, The Invisible Industry, Aero Publishers, 1978.Clemen, Rudolph * By Products in the Packing Industry, University of Chicago Press, 1927 * Franco, Don and Swanson, Winfield, The Original Recyclers, APPI, FPRF and NRA, 1996 {{refend}}

revision.text:
{{update|date=December 2016}} '''Sarepta Therapeutics Inc.''' ({{NASDAQ|SRPT}}) is a [[medical research]] and [[drug development]] company with [[corporation|corporate]] offices and research facilities in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], [[United States]]. Incorporated in 1980 as '''AntiVirals'''<ref name="founding">{{cite magazine | last=Summerton | first=J | year = 2005 | title=Morpholino Antisense Oligos: Applications in Biopharmaceutical Research. | journal = Innovations in Pharmaceutical Technology. |issue = Sept | url=http://www.iptonline.com/synopsis.asp?cat=4&article=303 | accessdate = 29 Oct 2012}} | archiveurl = http://www.gene-tools.com/sites/default/files/Summerton2005_IPT.pdf</ref>, shortly before going public the company changed its name from AntiVirals to '''AVI BioPharma''' soon with stock symbol AVII and in July 2012 changed name from AVI BioPharma to Sarepta Therapeutics and SRPT respectively.<ref name=name>{{cite news|title=AVI BioPharma changes name, splits stock|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/morning_call/2012/07/avi-biopharma-changes-name-splits-stock.html|accessdate=17 July 2012|newspaper=Portland Business Journal|date=July 12, 2012}}</ref> As of 2018, the company has one approved drug (see the Products section below).
==History== Sarepta started in Corvallis, Oregon<ref name="founding2">{{cite book | date= 2017 |chapter= Invention and Early History of Morpholinos |last1=Summerton |first1=James E. |title=Morpholino Oligomers |editor1-last=Moulton |editor1-first=Hong |editor2-last=Moulton |editor2-first=Jon |url=https://www.springer.com/us/book/9781493968152 |series=Methods in Molecular Biology |volume=1565 |location=New York, NY USA |publisher=Humana Press |isbn=978-1-4939-6815-2}}</ref>. After occupying several research laboratory spaces in Corvallis the company opened a production laboratory in Corvallis in February 2002 and was renamed AVI BioPharma Inc.<ref name="corvallis">{{cite news|url=http://portland.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2003/11/03/daily20.html|title=AVI BioPharma's losses shrinking|last=Moody|first=Robin J.|date=November 5, 2003|work=Portland Business Journal|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref> The company made headlines in 2003 when it announced work on treatments for [[severe acute respiratory syndrome]] (SARS) and the [[West Nile virus]].<ref name="corvallis"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://portland.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2003/06/09/daily40.html|title=AVI BioPharma stock reaches new 52-week high|last=Moody|first=Robin J.|date=June 12, 2003|work=Portland Business Journal|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref> In July 2009, the company announced they would move their headquarters from [[Portland, Oregon]], north to [[Bothell, Washington]], near [[Seattle]].<ref name="move">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2009/07/avi_biopharma_moving_hq_out_of.html|title=AVI BioPharma moving HQ out of Oregon|last=DiMesio|first=Robbie|date=July 30, 2009|work=[[The Oregonian]]|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref> At that time the company led by president and CEO Leslie Hudson had 83 employees and quarterly revenues of $3.2 million.<ref name="move"/> AVI had yet to turn a profit nor developed any commercial products as of July 2009.<ref name="move"/> The company lost $19.7 million in the second quarter of 2009,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://portland.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2009/08/10/daily2.html|title=AVI BioPharma loses $19.7M in Q2|date=August 10, 2009|work=Portland Business Journal|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref> and then won a $11.5 million contract with the [[U.S. Department of Defense]]'s [[Defense Threat Reduction Agency]] in October 2009.<ref name="military">{{cite news|url=http://portland.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2009/10/05/daily1.html|title=AVI BioPharma gets $11.5M military contract|date=October 5, 2009|work=Portland Business Journal|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref> By this time the company had completed its headquarters move to Bothell.<ref name="move"/><ref name="military"/>
In 2012 the company moved a second time, to Cambridge, Massachusetts. At the time, CEO Chris Garabedian indicated the move was motivated by the need to recruit expertise in [[rare disease]]s.<ref>Timmerman, Luke. [http://www.xconomy.com/seattle/2012/09/07/sarepta-moves-from-seattle-to-boston-to-recruit-more-talent/ Sarepta Moves From Seattle to Boston for the Talent.] 7 September 2012.</ref> The Corvallis laboratory facility was closed in 2016.
==Products== Its primary products are [[Morpholino]] oligomers (PMOs), synthetic nucleic acid analogs that were conceived of by James Summerton and invented by Summerton with Dwight Weller, originally developed under the name NeuGene Antisense. Since morpholino oligomers can form sequence-specific double-stranded complexes with RNA they are suitable use in [[antisense therapy]]. In one application, translation blocking, a morpholino oligomer binds to [[messenger RNA]] produced by a known disease-causing gene to prevent it from being [[gene translation|translated]] into protein. Morpholinos can also work as splice-switching olgos, targeting pre-mRNA to alter splicing and so causing changes in the structure of the mature mRNA (the mechanism of the approved drug eteplirsen). Morpholinos have been tested for a wide range of applications including prevention of cardiac [[restenosis]] after [[angioplasty]], treatment of coronary artery bypass grafts, treatment of polycystic kidney disease, redirection of drug metabolism, treatment of some mutations causing [[Duchenne muscular dystrophy|Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)]], and inhibition of infectious diseases. Their greatest clinical & commercial success thus far has been in treatment of DMD. A new class of Morpholino oligos, the peptide-linked Morpholinos or PPMO, are linked to an arginine-rich cell-penetrating peptide to enhance their delivery into cells and have entered clinical trials<ref>https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03375255</ref>
The Morpholino drug [[eteplirsen]], targeting exon 51 of the [[dystrophin]] mRNA, has been approved as a human therapeutic by the FDA in 2016<ref>http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm521263.htm</ref> and clinical trials for Morpholinos targeting other exons are ongoing. Morpholinos have been used in preclinical studies to inhibit replication of a broad range of viruses, including [[influenza]], [[West Nile Virus]], [[SARS]], [[Hepatitis C]], [[dengue fever]], [[Ebola]] and [[Calicivirus]], all of which are single stranded [[RNA virus]]es. They are in advanced development for prevention and treatment of Ebola and [[Marburg virus]]es. In March 2013, the Company announced positive results from a non-human primate study of AVI-7288, the drug candidate for treatment of Marburg virus infection. The results showed that intramuscular administration of AVI-7288 resulted in survival rates up to 100 percent in monkeys exposed to this fatal virus. These results are similar to those in previous studies when the drug was given by intravenous injection.<ref>[https://www.drugs.com/clinical_trials/sarepta-s-marburg-shows-survival-rates-after-intramuscular-delivery-non-human-primates-15214.html Sarepta's Marburg Drug Shows High Survival Rates After Intramuscular Delivery in Non-Human Primates.] Marketwire, 4 March 2013.</ref>
In addition to development of Morpholinos as therapeutics, AVI has conducted six human trials for [[colorectal]] and [[pancreatic]] cancers using their cancer [[vaccine]] [[AVICINE]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2018}} {{Spanish name|Piñera|Echenique}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Sebastián Piñera |image = Retrato Oficial Presidente Piñera 2018.jpg |caption = Sebastián Piñera in 2018 |order = 34th and 36th |office = President of Chile |term_start = 11 March 2018 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Michelle Bachelet]] |term_start1 = 11 March 2010 |term_end1 = 11 March 2014 |predecessor1 = Michelle Bachelet |successor1 = Michelle Bachelet |office2 = Leader of [[National Renewal (Chile)|National Renewal]] |term_start2 = 26 May 2001 |term_end2 = 10 March 2004 |predecessor2 = Alberto Cardemil |successor2 = Sergio Díez |office3 = [[Senate of Chile|Senator]] for [[Santiago Metropolitan Region|Eastern Santiago]] |term_start3 = 11 March 1990 |term_end3 = 11 March 1998 |predecessor3 = Position established |successor3 = Carlos Bombal |office4 = [[Pacific Alliance|President ''pro tempore'' of the Pacific Alliance]] |term_start4 = 5 March 2012 |term_end4 = 22 May 2013 |predecessor4 = ''Position established'' |successor4 = [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] |birth_name = Miguel Juan Sebastián Piñera Echenique |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1949|12|1}} |birth_place = [[Santiago]], Chile |party = [[National Renewal (Chile)|National Renewal]] (1989–present){{Efn|name=fn1|Membership suspended while President.}} |otherparty = [[Coalition for Change]] (2009–2013)
[[Chile Vamos]] (2015–present) |spouse = {{marriage|[[Cecilia Morel]]|December 1973}} |children = 4 |alma_mater = [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile]]
[[Harvard University]] |signature = Firma Sebastián Piñera.png |website = {{URL|sebastianpinera.cl|Official website}} }} '''Miguel Juan Sebastián Piñera Echenique''' ({{IPA-es|miˈɣel ˈxwan seβasˈtjan piˈɲeɾa etʃeˈnike|lang|sebapronunciation.ogg}}; born 1 December 1949) is the 36th and current [[President of Chile]], following [[Chilean general election, 2017|his election]] in December 2017. He also served as the 34th President from 2010 to 2014. == Family == Piñera is the sixth child of the marriage between [[José Piñera Carvallo]] and Magdalena Echenique Rozas. He was born on 1 December 1949, in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} His siblings are María Magdalena, [[José Piñera|José Manuel]], Juan Pablo, [[Miguel Piñera|José Miguel]], and María Teresa.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Sebastián Piñera's ancestry includes [[Basque people|Basque]], [[Cantabric]] and [[Amerindian]] roots.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Among his ancestors on his maternal side is his mother's great-great-grandmother, Luisa Pinto Garmendia, the sister of President [[Aníbal Pinto|Aníbal Pinto Garmendia]] and daughter of President [[Francisco Antonio Pinto]] and Luisa Garmendia Alurralde, who was a descendant of the last Inca emperor, [[Huayna Capac]].Retamal Favereau, Julio; Celis Atria, Carlos; y Muñoz Correa, Juan Guillermo – ''"Familias Fundadoras de Chile, 1540–1600"'', Editorial Universitaria, Santiago, 1992. pg. 789 He is a nephew of the oldest living Roman Catholic bishop in the world, [[Bernardino Piñera]].{{cite web|url=http://www.periodicoencuentro.cl/abril2010/ |title=Monseñor Bernardino Piñera y la relación con su sobrino Presidente|publisher=periodicoencuentro.cl|accessdate=22 September 2016}} == Education == Piñera's family moved to Belgium one year after his birth and later to [[New York City]], where his father was the Chilean ambassador to the United Nations.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Piñera returned to Chile in 1955 and enrolled in the [[Colegio del Verbo Divino]] ("Divine Word College"), from which he graduated in 1967.''{{es icon}} Universia [http://www.universia.cl/portada/actualidad/noticia_actualidad.jsp?noticia=120078 Sebastián Piñera Perfil] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207211052/http://www.universia.cl/portada/actualidad/noticia_actualidad.jsp?noticia=120078 |date=7 February 2015 }}'' Piñera then matriculated at the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile]], from which he graduated in 1971 with an undergraduate degree in commercial engineering. Upon graduation, he was awarded the Raúl Iver Oxley Prize, which is given to the best overall student of each class.{{Citation |url=http://diario.elmercurio.cl/detalle/index.asp?id=44b683ae-0698-4b29-a37e-54adbab1d7d3 |work=El Mercurio |title=Caminos cruzados |language=es}}. Piñera continued on to [[Harvard University]] on a partial [[Fulbright Program]] for [[postgraduate studies]] in economics. During his time at Harvard, Piñera and a classmate coauthored an article, "The Old South's Stake in the Inter-Regional Movement of Slaves", for the ''Journal of Economic History''.{{Citation |last=Kotlikoff |first=Laurence J. |last2=Piñera |first2=Sebastián |lastauthoramp=yes |title=The Old South's Stake in the Inter-Regional Movement of Slaves, 1850–1860 |journal=Journal of Economic History |volume=37 |issue=2 |year=1977 |pages=434–450 |jstor=2118765 |doi=10.1017/s002205070009700x}} After three years at Harvard, Piñera graduated with both an M.A. and Ph.D. in Economics.{{Citation |url=http://noticiassecretas.blogspot.com/2009/07/la-tesis-doctoral-de-sebastian-pinera.html |title=La tesis doctoral de Sebastián Piñera |date=30 July 2009 |first=Roberto Castillo |last=Sandoval |work=Noticias secretas |language=es}} == Teaching career == Piñera was an educator from 1971 until 1988. He was Professor of Economics at the [[University of Chile]], the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile]], and [[Adolfo Ibáñez University]]. In 1971, he was professor of Economic Political Theory in the School of Economics at the University of Chile and in 1972, he was a professor at the Valparaiso Business School.{{Citation |url=http://biografias.bcn.cl/pags/biografias/detalle_par.php?id=226 |title=Sebastián Piñera Echeñique — Senador |work=Reseñas parlamentarias — Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile |date= |language=es}} == Foundations == In 1989, with Cecilia Morel, Danica Radic, and Paula Délano, Piñera created the Enterprising Women Foundation (''Fundación Mujer Emprende''), originally called The House of Youth (''La Casa de la Juventud''). The foundation aims to assist in the development of young women of lower income.''{{es icon}} Fundacion Mujer Emprende [http://www.mujeremprende.cl/me_qs.php Quienes Somos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115140830/http://www.mujeremprende.cl/me_qs.php |date=15 January 2010 }}'' In 1973, Piñera created the foundation ''Fundación Futuro'', of which he is president and whose directors are Cristián Boza D., María Teresa Chadwick P., Hugo Montes B., Cecilia Morel M., Renato Poblete S.J., and Fabio Valdés C.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The head director of the foundation is Magdalena Piñera.{{Cite web|url=http://www.estrellaarica.cl/prontus4_nots/site/artic/20100423/pags/20100423170525.html|title=Magdalena Piñera, directora de la Fundación Futuro lanzó "Ojo con el Ejército de Chile" (Video)|website=www.estrellaarica.cl|access-date=19 December 2017}}{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The foundation’s mission is to help in Chile’s development of justice, freedom and democracy.''{{es icon}} Fundanción Futuro [http://www.fundacionfuturo.cl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=43&Itemid=20 Quienes Somos]'' The foundation was renamed ''Fundación Cultura y Sociedad'' after Piñera was elected president.''{{es icon}} Terra [http://economia.terra.cl/noticias/noticia.aspx?idNoticia=201002091001_INV_78739381 Semana clave para fundación a la que Piñera traspasará propiedad de Chilevisión]'' Under the ''Fundación Cultura y Sociedad'' (formerly ''Fundación Futuro''), the ''Grupo Tantauco'' has the mission of [[environmentalism]], and is administered by Juan Carlos Urquidi.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} It was created to support the proposals Piñera plans to institute during his presidency.''{{es icon}} Piñera2010 [http://pinera2010.cl/2009/09/22/conoce-las-propuestas-medioambientales-del-grupo-tantauco/ Conoce las propuestas medioambientales del Grupo Tantauco] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091207222157/http://pinera2010.cl/2009/09/22/conoce-las-propuestas-medioambientales-del-grupo-tantauco/ |date=7 December 2009 }}'' In 2005, Piñera created [[Tantauco Park]] (Spanish: ''Parque Tantauco''), a 1,180 km2 (456 sq mi) private natural reserve he bought and owns on the south end of Chiloé Island, in order to protect 118,000 hectares of the region's unique ecosystem. His foundation runs the park, which is open to the public and is an [[ecotourist]] location.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In fact, Piñera bought the 118,000 hectares in Chiloé through an [[offshore company]] in Panama. He has faced pressure to cede eight hectares to 16 indigenous families whose presence pre-dates Piñera's purchase and who have spent years negotiating to obtain title to their familial lands.https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-landrights-island/mystical-islanders-divided-over-chiles-giant-bridge-project-idUSKCN1GD5JEhttp://www.elmostrador.cl/noticias/pais/2017/06/09/familias-que-viven-en-tantauco-presionan-a-pinera-para-que-entregue-hectareas-antes-de-las-primarias An additional project, ''Grupo Tantauco: Derechos Humanos'', was proposed in hopes of beginning a reconciliation between the Chilean people who suffered human rights violations during [[Augusto Pinochet]]'s dictatorship.''{{es icon}} Piñera2010 [http://www.pinera2010.cl/2008/12/05/este-miercoles-se-lanza-nuevo-grupo-tantauco-derechos-humanos/ Grupo Tantauco: Derechos Humanos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116222334/http://pinera2010.cl/2008/12/05/este-miercoles-se-lanza-nuevo-grupo-tantauco-derechos-humanos/ |date=16 November 2009 }}'' == Businesses == Piñera was general manager of the {{ill|Banco de Talca|es|Banco de Talca|WD=https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banco_de_Talca}}. In 1982, a warrant was issued for his arrest on charges of violating banking law. Piñera spent 24 days in hiding while his lawyers appealed the order. A [[writ of habeas corpus]], first rejected by the Appeals Court but then approved by the Supreme Court, acquitted Piñera.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnd.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20090418/pags/20090418205903.html|title=lnd.cl|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}} Piñera once owned 90% of [[Chilevisión]] (a [[terrestrial television]] channel broadcasting nationwide). He also owned 27% of [[LAN Airlines]] (LAN);{{Cite news|url=http://en.mercopress.com/2010/04/21/chilean-president-to-sell-holding-in-television-network-160-million-usd|title=Chilean president to sell holding in television network: 160 million USD|work=MercoPress|access-date=19 December 2017}} 13% of [[Colo-Colo]],{{Citation |url=http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20070820/pags/20070820210305.html |title=Piñera aumenta participación en Colo Colo |newspaper=La Nación |date=21 August 2007 |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604015702/http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20070820/pags/20070820210305.html |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df= }} a football (soccer) club; and other minor stock positions in companies such as Quiñenco, [[Enersis]], and Soquimich.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In July 2007, Piñera was fined approximately 10 [[USD]] by Chile's securities regulator (SVS) for not withdrawing a purchase order after receiving privileged information (an infraction similar to [[insider trading]]) of LAN Airlines stock in mid-2006.''[[Ethisphere Magazine]]: [http://ethisphere.com/insider-trading-global-push-continues-as-former-chilean-presidential-candidate-slapped-with-680k-fine/ Insider Trading] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610053158/http://ethisphere.com/insider-trading-global-push-continues-as-former-chilean-presidential-candidate-slapped-with-680k-fine/ |date=10 June 2009 }}'' Piñera denied any wrongdoing and asserted that the charge was part of a political attack to damage his image.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} He did not appeal, stating that the court process could take years and interfere with his intention to run again for president in 2009.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Later that month, he resigned from the boards of LAN and [[Quintec]].''{{Citation |url=http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias/site/artic/20070731/pags/20070731222739.html |newspaper=La Nación |title=Piñera deja el directorio de Lan y su socio Cueto inicia apelación por multa de SVS |date=1 August 2007 |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604015717/http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias/site/artic/20070731/pags/20070731222739.html |archivedate=4 June 2011 |df= }}'' To avoid a conflict of interest he sold Chilevisión for $160 million in 2010 to [[Time Warner]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cd5079e8-b07a-11df-8c04-00144feabdc0,s01=1.html|title=Time Warner buys Chile TV network|work=Financial Times|accessdate=27 April 2016}} He also sold his shares of LAN in several rounds between February and March 2010,{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKN2423692520100324 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 4-Chile's Pinera to sell remaining LAN stake | date=24 March 2010}} as well as his stake in Colo-Colo. Piñera has built an estimated fortune of [[United States dollar|$US]]2.8 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] {{as of|2018|02|lc=on}}, according to ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine.{{Citation |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sebastian-pinera |title=Sebastian Pinera — Forbes|work=Forbes: The World's Billionaires |date=27 February 2018 }} His wealth is greatly due to his involvement in introducing [[credit card]]s to Chile in the late 1970s and his subsequent investments, mainly in [[LAN Airlines]] stock. Piñera acquired shares of the formerly state-owned company from [[Scandinavian Airlines]] in 1994, as part of a joint venture with the Cueto family."[http://www.lan.com/files/about_us/lanchile/memoria2007.pdf LAN Airlines 2007 annual report, p. 29]" ''. == Political career == {{see also|Political positions of Sebastián Piñera}} Piñera declared that he voted ''No'' in the [[Chilean national plebiscite, 1988|1988 plebiscite]] on whether [[Augusto Pinochet]] should stay in power until 1997 (even though it was a secret ballot).{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In 1988 as Pinochet had lost the referendum and Chile was [[Chilean transition to democracy|returning to democracy]] Piñera offered his support for the [[Christian Democrat Party of Chile|Christian Democrat]] [[Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle]] in his pre-candidacy for president.{{cite web|url=http://diario.latercera.com/2011/01/22/01/contenido/opinion/11-56835-9-pinera-y-sus-raices-dc.shtml|title=La Tercera|author=COPESA, Consorcio Periodistico de Chile S.A.|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}} Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle was the son of former president [[Eduardo Frei Montalva]], who had together with Piñera's father founded the Christian Democrat Party of Chile and had been appointed ambassador by Frei Montalva.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} However, in 1989 Sebastián Piñera headed the presidential campaign of [[Hernán Büchi]], a former finance minister of the Pinochet government.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} During the same election process, Piñera was elected as Senator for East Santiago (1990–1998) and soon after, joined the center-right [[National Renewal (Chile)|National Renewal]] Party.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} During his term as Senator he was a member of the Senate Finance Committee.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In 1992, Piñera's attempt to become his party's candidate for the following year's [[Chilean presidential election, 1993|Presidential election]] dramatically ended after he was involved in a scandal known as Piñeragate, wherein a wiretapped conversation between himself and a friend was revealed during a political television show he attended.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the conversation—made public by the television station's owner, Ricardo Claro—he conspired to have his rival for the party's nomination, [[Evelyn Matthei]], cornered during the show by a journalist close to Piñera.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The tape was then revealed to have been illegally recorded by a member of the military and given to Matthei, who then gave it to Claro.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Matthei stepped down from the presidential race as well.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In 1998, Piñera opposed the [[Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet|arrest and detention of Augusto Pinochet]], in London, initiated by [[Baltasar Garzón]], arguing that it was an attack on the sovereignty and dignity of [[Chile]].[http://www.lanacion.cl/pinera-y-su-acalorado-apoyo-a-pinochet-en-1998/noticias/2009-12-10/141341.html Piñera y su acalorado apoyo a Pinochet en 1998] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622063147/http://www.lanacion.cl/pinera-y-su-acalorado-apoyo-a-pinochet-en-1998/noticias/2009-12-10/141341.html |date=22 June 2011 }}. ''La Nación'', 10 de diciembre de 2009 (part of the speech can be seen at {{YouTube|TV-Ulfo09Bs}}). Piñera was president of his party from 2001 to 2004.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} He tried to run for Senator in 2001, but resigned his campaign after the presidential candidate of his alliance -and member of the allied party, the [[Independent Democratic Union]] (UDI)-, [[Joaquín Lavín]] made it clear he would not support candidates from Piñera's party, insisting on supporting retired [[Admiral]] Jorge Arancibia instead.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} On 14 May 2005, in a surprise move Piñera announced his candidacy for the [[Chilean presidential election, 2005|2005 presidential election]] (RN was supposed to support UDI's Lavín.) He has described his political philosophy as [[Christian humanism]].{{cite web |url= http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2006/01/12/internacional/1137096398.html|title= Sebastián Piñera: la nueva derecha que se desprende de la dictadura|trans-title= Sebastián Piñera: the new right that sets apart from the dictatorship|language= Spanish|author= |date= 16 January 2006|publisher= El Mundo|accessdate=18 December 2017}} In the first round of the election, on 11 December, he obtained 25.4% of the vote, which placed him in second place.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Since no candidate achieved an [[absolute majority]], a [[Two-round system|runoff election]] was held on 15 January 2006, between himself and of the governing coalition. Bachelet won the presidency with over 53% of the vote.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} === Presidential elections of 2009–2010 === [[File:Piñera Presidente electo.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Piñera celebrated victory alongside wife and family in 2010.]] {{Main|Chilean presidential election, 2009–2010}} Piñera ran for President of Chile in the 2009–2010 election.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Sebastian-Pinera|title=Sebastian Pinera {{!}} Biography, Facts, & Presidency|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=19 December 2017|language=en}} Since August 2009, he led in opinion polls, competing with [[Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle]], [[Marco Enríquez-Ominami]] and [[Jorge Arrate]]; all of whom are left-of-center candidates.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the 13 December 2009 election, Piñera placed first in the results with 44.05% of the votes, while Frei placed second with 29.6% of the votes.{{Cite web|url=http://electionresources.org/cl/president.php?election=2009|title=Election Resources on the Internet: Presidential and Legislative Elections in Chile - Results Lookup|website=electionresources.org|access-date=19 December 2017}} Neither candidate received more than half of the total votes; therefore, according to the Constitution, Chileans returned to the polls for a final run-off election on Sunday, 17 January 2010.{{Citation |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126075115772389867 |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |title=Billionaire Leads Chile Election |date=14 December 2009 |first=Matt |last=Moffett }} That evening, the third and final preliminary results were announced by the Deputy [[Ministry of the Interior (Chile)|Interior Ministry]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} These showing accounted for 99.77% of the total ballot boxes.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Of the votes, Piñera received 51.61% and Frei received 48.39%.''{{es icon}} Republica de Chile [http://www.elecciones.gov.cl/Sitio2009/index.html Votación Candidatos por País] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123074649/http://www.elecciones.gov.cl/Sitio2009/index.html |date=23 January 2010 }}'' Eduardo Frei conceded after the first preliminary results, making Sebastián Piñera the new President-elect of Chile.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Further results were released by the Chilean Electoral Service on 25 January 2010.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Official and final results sanctioned by the Election Qualifying Court were published on the Official Gazette on 1 February 2010.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} [[File:Presidenta_Bachelet_y_Presidente-electo_Piñera.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Piñera meeting with Michelle Bachelet during the presidential transition.]] Piñera invested an estimated 13.6 million [[USD]] in his presidential campaign, which included items such as a campaign anthem{{cite web|url=http://pinera2010.cl/2009/12/13/himno-de-campana/|title=''Piñera's Campaign Anthem''|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217174929/http://pinera2010.cl/2009/12/13/himno-de-campana/|archivedate=17 December 2009|df=dmy-all}} and "Thank You" banners.{{cite web|url=http://pinera2010.cl/2009/12/14/gracias-gracias-gracias/|title=''Piñera's Thank you Banners''|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218082156/http://pinera2010.cl/2009/12/14/gracias-gracias-gracias/|archivedate=18 December 2009|df=dmy-all}} Piñera's banners and billboards have carried statements throughout the country such as "Delinquents, your party is over," and "Small businesses, Big opportunities".{{cite web|url=http://cache.daylife.com/imageserve/09DZgcM3Zr1mQ/429x.jpg|title=''Piñera Campaign Billboard''|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204124017/http://cache.daylife.com/imageserve/09DZgcM3Zr1mQ/429x.jpg|archivedate=4 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} Piñera's campaign released a {{YouTube|iUPd_sLPZ5g|national TV spot}} featuring a male [[gay]] couple, something never seen before in a presidential campaign run in Chile. Amongst his promises were increasing education rates and improving international relations with the neighboring country of Perú.{{cite web|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/news-10897-latin-america-chilean-candidate-pinera-says-hell-maintain-good-relations-with-peru-if-elected|title=Peru this Week|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}} Piñera's victory meant a shift towards the right,{{Citation |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0922773120091209 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 December 2009 |title=Chile right seen ousting left in first since Pinochet |first=Simon |last=Gardner }} breaking two-decades of center-left political leadership and becoming the first elected right-wing leader in 52 years.''PBS Newshour [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2010/01/radical-change-in-chile-with-new-right-wing-president.html Chile Elects First Right-Wing President in 52 Years]'' On 28 January, Piñera suspended his membership in National Renewal, becoming unofficially an [[Independent (politician)|independent]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} RN's bylaws require successful presidential candidates from the party to renounce their association in order to govern the country fairly, foremost with the interest of the people, not with the interest of a political party or particular political philosophy.{{es icon}} El Economista [http://eleconomista.com.mx/internacional/2010/01/28/pinera-renuncia-su-militancia-gobernar http://eleconomista.com.mx/internacional/2010/01/28/pinera-renuncia-su-militancia-gobernar Piñera renuncia a su militancia para gobernar] === Private to public transition === {{Infobox Chile Cabinet November 2013 |Sports end =11 March 2014 }} Piñera became the first billionaire to be sworn into the Chilean Presidency.{{Citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/15/international/americas/15chile.html |title=Chile Is Ready to Elect a President Unlike Any Other |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=15 January 2006 |last=Rohter |first=Larry }} He offered to sell his [[shares]] in major [[corporations]] before being sworn in on 11 March 2010, in order to avoid [[conflicts of interest]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Piñera has placed US$400 million in [[blind trust]]s. ''Reuters [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2014340920100120 UPDATE 1-Chile's Piñera begins LAN stake sale process]'' The Monday following Piñera's election, expectations of sale from his largest holdings created a surge in trade of Axxion and LAN shares, causing three brief suspensions ( 19–20 January 22, 2010) in the [[Santiago Stock Exchange]] in order to ease trade. Axxion shares more than tripled before falling 39% on Friday, 22 January.''The Wall Street Journal [https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100122-709688.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLEHeadlinesAmericas Chile Piñera's Axxion Falls 39% After Trading Resumes]'' Bachelet's Finance Minister Andrés Velasco urged Piñera to get the sale "sorted out quickly."''Bloomberg Business Week [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-22/axxion-falls-after-post-election-surge-as-halt-lifted-update2-.html Axxion Falls After Post-Election Surge as Halt Lifted (Update2)]'' The value of Piñera's interest in Axxion was estimated at 700 million dollars [[USD]], of his 1.2 billion dollar [[USD]] fortune at the beginning of that week''Canada.com [http://www.canada.com/news/Chile+billionaire+president+profits+from+share+surge/2464390/story.html Chile's billionaire new president profits from share surge]''. On 5 February, Piñera confirmed plans to sell his 26.3% stake in LAN airlines at an [[Extraordinary General Meeting|extraordinary shareholders' meeting]] for his main holding company, Axxion.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Under the pact, Axxion shareholders have agreed to fix the price of the sale, estimated at 1.5 billion USD. The Cueto family, who at that point held 25.5% of LAN through their holding company ''Costa Verde Aeronáutica'', had the first option to purchase the stake.''Reuters [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0514886220100205 Piñera's Axxion approves LAN stake sale]'' On 18 February, Axxion posted a statement on their website confirming the sale of a 21.18% stake in LAN Airlines to the Cueto family for 1.23 billion USD.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Announcement regarding the sale of the remaining shares was pending until March 2010, when the whole package left Piñera's hands.''Reuters [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1820116620100218?type=marketsNews UPDATE 2-Chile's Pinera offers Cuetos $1.23 bln LAN stake]'' Piñera sold his 9.7% stake in the upscale private hospital ''Clinica Las Condes'' at a price of 25,113 [[Chilean peso|CLP]] per share (48.00 USD) through his holding company Bancard on Tuesday, 16 February. The total sale of the 792,000 shares [[Gross (economics)|grossed]] 37.85 million USD and was purchased by the brokerage firm ''Celfin''.''{{es icon}} La Universal [http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/659287.html Piñera vende acciones de clínica en Chile]'' The proceeds from the sale will go to paying off Bancard debt.''Bloomberg [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601086&sid=aduh2KzYIPZU Pinera to Auction 36 million USD Las Condes Stake (Update1) ]'' [[File:Sebastián Piñera - David Cameron.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Piñera with [[David Cameron]], [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], outside [[10 Downing Street]], [[London]].]] Piñera announced on February he had the intention to transfer 100% of his stake in [[Chilevisión]] to a non-for-profit organization called ''Fundación Cultura y Sociedad'' (formerly ''Fundación Futuro''), of which he is owner.''{{es icon}} La Nacion [http://www.lanacion.cl/cuestionan-formula-de-fundacion-para-chilevision/noticias/2010-02-08/210939.html Cuestionan fórmula de fundación para Chilevisión]'' The foundation's board will include some of the station's current executives. Under that proposal, Piñera maintains the right to remove and replace the foundation's president at any given time.''{{es icon}} Radio Bio Bio [http://www.radiobiobio.cl/2010/02/08/ex-fundacion-futuro-cambia-de-funcion-y-queda-como-duena-de-las-acciones-de-chilevision/ Ex “Fundación Futuro” cambia de función y queda como dueña de las acciones de Chilevisión]'' [[Cristián Larroulet|Cristián Patricio Larroulet Vignau]], current Minister of the Secretariat of the Presidency of Chile, stated that Piñera was honouring his promise of removing himself from private corporations, as Chilevision will become the property of a [[non-profit organization]]. [[Member of Parliament|MP]] Cristián Monckeberg ([[National Renewal (Chile)|RN]]), stated there is no law obligating Piñera to do otherwise and thus this decision is legally legitimate.''''. The option above finally did not take place, Piñera decided to sell the TV station, and after a failed attempt in May 2010 with the Linzor Capital investment fund,{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64E22V20100515 | work=Reuters | title=Chilean President Pinera sells TV station | date=15 May 2010}} the President announced it sold Chilevisión to [[Time Warner]], in late August 2010. Piñera said he won't sell his 12.5% stake in ''Blanco y Negro'', company that owns the nation's popular soccer team [[Colo-Colo]]. He has stated, "We want big things and not only achieve local victories. The idea is to return the [[Copa Libertadores]] to Chile. That is our great goal."''El Economista [http://eleconomista.com.mx/deportes/2010/01/19/colo-colo-pasion-pine Colo-Colo, la pasión de Piñera]'' Although he will remain part owner, he will take no administrative duties or role while President.''{{es icon}} El Diario Exterior [http://www.eldiarioexterior.com/el-presidente-empresario-37525.htm El presidente empresario]'' === Council of Ministers === {{Main|Ministries of Chile}} Piñera announced what he calls his "cabinet of unity" on Tuesday, 9 February 2010, at 18:00 hours (local time), in Chile's National Historical Museum.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The list of names was presented the previous day to the leader of the National Renewal Party, Carlos Larraín, and the leader of the Independent Democratic Union, Juan Antonio Coloma.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The cabinet is made up of 16 men and 6 women, with an average age of 49.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Amongst Piñera's nominees is Jaime Ravinet, who is defense minister of the current president's cabinet and a former member of the Christian Democratic Party, from which he resigned upon accepting Piñera's cabinet offer.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Also a nominee is Cristián Larroulet, who was an economic planning adviser under [[Augusto Pinochet|Pinochet]].''Financial Times [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/375c90e4-15d8-11df-b65b-00144feab49a.html?nclick_check=1 Chile’s Piñera unveils ‘cabinet of unity’]'' During his first official meeting with his Council of Ministers on Wednesday, 10 February, Piñera issued a formal [[memorandum]] calling upon all members to [[Abdication|renounce]] their positions in all [[Privately held company|private companies]] by 28 February in order to avoid conflicts of interest.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The memorandum also said that in regards to [[Cultural heritage|national heritage]], secretaries of state whose [[Partnership|affiliation]] with companies having direct receipt of [[finance|fiscal]] monies must either remove themselves from those associations or honor the restrictions of their competitors.''{{es icon}} Europa Press [http://www.europapress.es/latam/chile/noticia-chile-pinera-pide-futuros-ministros-renunciar-cargos-empresas-antes-28-febrero-20100211215337.html Piñera pide a sus futuros ministros renunciar a sus cargos en empresas antes del 28 de febrero]'' Ten of his 22 ministers have involvement in companies with significant financial means.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} === 2017 presidential elections === [[File:Logo Piñera Presidente 2V.svg|thumb|Piñera's campaign logo in the second round of the election]] {{Main|Chilean general election, 2017}} On 17 December 2017, Sebastián Piñera was [[chilean general election, 2017|elected]] [[president of Chile]] for a second term.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-42388019|title=Conservative is Chilean president again|date=18 December 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} He received 36% of the votes, the highest percentages among all 8 candidates in the 2017 elections. In the second round, Piñera faced Alejandro Guillier, a television news anchor who represented Bachelet’s New Majority (Nueva Mayoría) coalition. Piñera won the elections with 54% of the votes. == First presidency (2010–2014) == [[File:Sebastián Piñera asume como Presidente de Chile en solemne ceremonia en el Congreso Nacional.jpg|thumb|Piñera receives the [[presidential sash]] from Senate President [[Jorge Pizarro]] at the [[National Congress of Chile]] on 11 March 2010.]] [[File:Fotografía oficial del Presidente Sebastián Piñera - 2.jpg|170px|thumb|left|Piñera's official portrait for his first term as president.]] [[File:Sebastián Piñera, Fotografía Oficial junto a su gabinete ministerial (3).jpg|thumb|Sebastián Piñera and his [[Ministries of Chile|Council of Ministers]] in Chile's Palacio de Cerro Castillo]] Piñera was sworn in as the 35th President of the Republic of Chile on 11 March 2010, in a ceremony held in a plenary session of the [[National Congress of Chile|National Congress]] in [[Valparaíso]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the same ceremony, Piñera's Cabinet ministers were sworn in. The ceremony was also marked by a [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake|6.9 Mw earthquake and subsequent aftershocks]] that upset the invitees.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/11/06/trump-trailblazers-chilean-among-other-billionaires-who-turned-to-politics.html|title=Not the only one: Ex-Chilean leader among other billionaires who turned to politics|date=6 November 2016|work=Fox News|access-date=19 December 2017|language=en-US}} Shortly after, the National Congress building was evacuated due to a [[tsunami warning system|tsunami alert]] that proved to be false a couple of hours later.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} On 12 October 2010, Piñera rallied his countrymen in the [[2010 Copiapó mining accident|rescue of 33 trapped miners]], all of whom were rescued after 70 days following a [[2010 Copiapó mining accident|mining accident]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} "Chile will never be the same", he said to the miners' foreman, Luis Urzúa, as he (the last of the miners to emerge from the cavern) greeted Piñera, in a broadcast carried live across the globe.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Despite much goodwill in Chile following this, many Chileans{{Who|date=December 2017}} are still waiting on Piñera to rectify anti-terrorism laws in Chile which effectively mean the indigenous Mapuche people can be dealt with as "terrorists".{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} This matter has led to hunger strikes which started before the mining disaster, and are set to continue afterwards.{{cite web|url=http://www.soundsandcolours.com/articles/chile/mapuche-hunger-strike-in-chile-highlights-the-real-problem-facing-president-sebastian-pinera/|title=Mapuche hunger strike in Chile highlights the real problem facing President Sebastián Piñera|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}} In January 2011 he faced the [[2011 Magallanes protests|protest in Magallanes Region]] in response to a proposed increase in the price of natural gas there by 16.8%.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The protests left more than two thousand cars isolated while trying to cross from the [[Tierra del Fuego Province (Argentina)|Argentine province of Tierra del Fuego]] to the [[Santa Cruz Province, Argentina|province of Santa Cruz]] through Chilean territory. Another 1,500 tourists were left without movement in [[Torres del Paine National Park]] after routes to Puerto Natales and El Calafate were cut.{{cite news|url=http://www.theclinic.cl/2011/01/11/minuto-a-minuto-partio-el-puntarenazo/|publisher=The Clinic|title=Minuto a minuto: Masivo acto en apoyo a Magallanes frente a La Moneda|date=11 January 2011|access-date=12 January 2011|language=Spanish}} In consequence, on 14 January, [[Ministry General Secretariat of Government (Chile)|Minister Secretary General of Government]] [[Ena von Baer]] announced changes in Sebastián Piñera's government cabinet, including the resignation of [[Ricardo Raineri]] as Energy Minister. [[Laurence Golborne]] became [[Ministry of Mining (Chile)|Mining]] and [[Ministry of Energy (Chile)|Energy]] Minister, on 16 January.{{cite news|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=458544|title=Piñera concreta su primer cambio de gabinete al aceptar la renuncia a otros tres ministros|publisher=[[El Mercurio|El Mercurio Online]]|date=14 January 2011|access-date=15 January 2011}} In March 2011, President Piñera led a state visit to [[Spain]] to boost relations between the two countries.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} While in Spain, President and Mrs Piñera, with [[Felipe, Prince of Asturias|Prince Felipe]] and [[Princess Letizia]], opened the exhibition ”Don Qui. El Quijote de Matta”, at the [[Cervantes Institute]] of [[Madrid]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cervantes.es/sobre_instituto_cervantes/prensa/2011/noticias/discurso_memorando_chile.htm|title=Los Príncipes y el presidente de Chile inauguran en el Instituto Cervantes "Don Qui. El Quijote de Matta". Notas de prensa 2011. Sala de prensa. Instituto Cervantes|trans-title=|language=Spanish|first=Instituto|last=Cervantes|website=www.Cervantes.es|access-date=19 December 2017}} Amidst the severe [[2011 student protests in Chile|2011 Chilean student protest]]s Piñera shuffled his cabinet and removed [[Joaquín Lavín]] from the post of minister of education. With respect to the protest, Piñera has defended [[for-profit]] activity in education and proposed to legalize it, rejecting the students' demands for the public ownership of educational establishments.{{cite web|url=http://www.gob.cl/destacados/2011/07/05/cadena-nacional-de-radio-y-television-presidente-pinera-anuncio-gran-acuerdo-nacional-por-la-educaci.htm|title=Cadena Nacional de Radio y Televisión: Presidente Piñera anunció Gran Acuerdo Nacional por la Educación|trans-title=|language=Spanish|date=5 July 2011|website=www.Gob.cl|access-date=19 December 2017}} During August 2011, Piñera's public approval declined precipitously amidst continuous protests, to the extent that some polls indicated that he was the least popular Chilean leader since Augusto Pinochet. His approval ratings dropped to as low as 22% according to a CERC survey.http://www.cerc.cl {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121073833/http://www.cerc.cl/ |date=21 November 2013 }} As such, Piñera's chances of passing sought reforms were seen as remote.[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c1e72b62-d011-11e0-81e2-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1X5tfH7X0 Teen shot in Chile anti-Piñera protest dies] [[Financial Times]]. 26 August 2011. 26 August 2011 As president, Piñera expressed support for the [[Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute|Argentine claim on the Falkland Islands]], referring to "the unrenounceable rights of Argentina on the islands".[http://blogs.elmercurio.com/columnasycartas/2012/01/06/chile-y-las-malvinas.asp Chile y las Malvinas], [[Juan Gabriel Valdés]]. Blogs ''[[El Mercurio]]''. 6 January 2012. In March 2012, Piñera visited [[Vietnam]] with the intention of increasing cooperation between the two countries in general and with [[Ho Chi Minh City]], Vietnam's most populous and largest economic hub, in particular.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} HCM City also called for a Chilean sister city while receiving Piñera on 23 March.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The visit included the signing of a bilateral trade agreement and several cooperation pacts in education, tourism, culture and finance.{{cite web|url=http://en.baomoi.com/Info/Vietnam-Chile-seek-stronger-ties/3/247906.epi|title=Vietnam, Chile seek stronger ties|language=|date=|website=Baomoi.com|access-date=}} ===Criticism=== [[File:Aprobacion_Sebastian_Piñera.png|thumb|Levels of approval (blue) and disapproval (red) of Piñera's term from 2010 to 2014, according to the Adimark survey. Piñera left office in March 2014 with an approval rating of 50%.]] Early in 2012 physicist [[F. J. Duarte|Frank Duarte]] sharply criticized Piñera's performance in the handling of the [[Chilean–Peruvian maritime dispute]] at The Hague, deemed as favoring commercial interests over the interest of the Chilean people, and called for Chile's withdrawal from The Hague.{{cite web|url=http://www.elvoluntario.com/index20120229.shtml|title=EL VOLUNTARIO|trans-title=|language=Spanish|date= 27–29 February 2012|website=www.ElVoluntario.com|access-date=19 December 2017}} Following the adverse ruling against Chile in 2014, several political figures in Chile, from a variety of political parties, also called for Chile's withdrawal from The Hague that would, in addition, imply a withdrawal from the [[Pact of Bogota]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lasegunda.com/Noticias/Politica/2014/01/910056/fuertes-criticas-de-parlamentarios-aqui-chile-no-ha-ganado-nada-hemos-perdido|title=Fuertes críticas de parlamentarios: "Aquí Chile no ha ganado nada... hemos perdido"|trans-title=|language=|first=El Mercurio|last=S.A.P.|date=27 January 2014|website=LaSegunda.com|access-date=19 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.estrellaarica.cl/impresa/2014/01/27/full/4/|title=Página 4 - La Estrella de Arica - 27.01.2014|trans-title=|language=|date=27 January 2014|website=EstrellaArica.cl|access-date=19 December 2017}} In December 2011 during a state visit to [[Mexico]] a joke made by Piñera where he compared women with politicians caused uproar in Chile, sparking criticism from his own minister [[Carolina Schmidt]] who said of the joke that it was "hurting to many women".[http://www.latercera.com/noticia/politica/2011/12/674-410092-9-ministra-schmidt-por-broma-de-pinera-el-chiste-no-solo-es-fome-sino-que-hiriente.shtml Ministra Schmidt por broma de Piñera: "El chiste no sólo es fome, sino que hiriente para muchas mujeres"], ''[[La Tercera]]''. In the joke Piñera said that "when a lady says "no" it means maybe, when she says maybe it means yes and when she says yes she is not a lady."[http://elcomercio.pe/mundo/1344802/noticia-sebastian-pinera-criticado-chiste-machista-cumbre-mexico Sebastián Piñera criticado por chiste machista en cumbre de México], ''[[El Comercio (Peru)|El Comercio]]. The Chilean Network Against Domestic and Sexual Violence called the joke "misogynic" and "a shame for the whole country". Previously on a state visit to Peru in 2011 Piñera received criticism for his informal style after he revealed to Peruvian president-elect [[Ollanta Humala]] that he was a descendant of the Inca [[Huayna Capac]].[http://www.cambio21.cl/cambio21/site/artic/20110616/pags/20110616174729.html "Las Piñerías o Piñericosas siguen siendo el hazmerreir del gobierno. Piñera asegura ser descendiente de un emperador inca. Sociólogo Pablo Hunneus, senador Jorge Pizarro y diputado Fidel Espinoza le critican la escasa dignidad que imprime al cargo". June 16, 2011. ''Cambio 21''.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619012734/http://www.cambio21.cl/cambio21/site/artic/20110616/pags/20110616174729.html |date=19 June 2011 }} Senator [[Jorge Pizarro]] criticized Piñera's comment to Ollanta Humala, calling for more careful and respectful attitudes.{{cite web|url=http://elcomercio.pe/politica/782705/noticia-humala-pinera-descendiente-inca-huayna-capac|title=Para Humala, Piñera es descendiente del inca Huayna Cápac|work=El Comercio|access-date=27 April 2016}} == Second presidency (2018–present) == {{Infobox President styles |image=[[File:Flag of the President of Chile.svg|border|75px]] |name=Sebastián Piñera |dipstyle= ''Su Excelencia, el Presidente de la República''.
"His Excellency, the President of the Republic" |offstyle= ''Presidente de Chile''.
"President of Chile" |altstyle= ''Señor Presidente''.
"Mr. President" }} [[File:Sebastián Piñera asume como Presidente de Chile y da inicio su segundo mandato 5.jpg|thumb|President Sebastian Piñera receives presidential sash and the O'Higgins Pioche for the second time, 11 March 2018]] {{further|List of presidential trips made by Sebastián Piñera}} On December 17th, Piñera won the second round of the [[Chilean general election, 2017|Chilean General election]], defeating the left wing candidate [[Alejandro Guillier]] to become President-Elect. Piñera took office for a second time on March 11th, 2018, succeeding the outgoing [[Michelle Bachelet]]. ===Cabinet=== In January 2018, Piñera unveiled his [[Far-right politics|hardline]] cabinet to harsh criticism: his interior minister, [[Andrés Chadwick]], was a vocal supporter of Pinochet [[dictatorship]], which had previously appointed him president of the Catholic University Students Federation.https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/23/chile-president-elect-sebastian-pinera-andres-chadwick In 2012 Chadwick expressed "deep repentance" for this support after discovering "over the years" serious human rights violations committed by the dictatorship, while defending the regime on other grounds.https://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/pais/augusto-pinochet/chadwick-por-su-rol-en-dictadura-me-arrepiento-de-no-haber-hecho-algo-mas/2012-06-11/130659.html Chadwick and justice minister [[Hernán Larraín]] were also "supporters and defenders of the secretive German enclave Colonia Dignidad, which was established by the fugitive [[Nazi]] officer and [[paedophile]] [[Paul Schäfer]] in the early 60s," according to the Guardian UK.https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/23/chile-president-elect-sebastian-pinera-andres-chadwick Colonia Dignidad was used by Pinochet security officials to [[torture]] and murder opponents of the regime.https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/23/chile-president-elect-sebastian-pinera-andres-chadwickhttps://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/aljazeeracorrespondent/2013/10/tales-torture-2013103081121394171.html Other appointees with [[far-right]] ties include [[Isabel Plá]], an anti-abortion advocate appointed to the Ministry of Women and Gender Equality, and mining minister [[Baldo Prokurica]], a governor under the Pinochet regime.https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Chiles-Pinera-Announces-Far-Right-Cabinet-Picks-20180123-0024.html == Public image == Piñera is associated with bad luck.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/01/120110_cono_sur_chile_presidente_mala_suerte_psicologia_vh.shtml Piñera y los presidentes tachados de "mala suerte"]. [[BBC]]. The BBC has listed a series of situations of "bad luck" concerning Piñera's presidency: the [[2010 Maule earthquake]] followed by [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake|another quake]] during Piñera's inauguration ceremony, the [[2010 Copiapó mining accident|mining accident of 2010]], the [[2010 Santiago prison fire]], the [[2011 Puyehue-Cordón Caulle eruption]] and the [[2012 Araucanía wildfires|2012 wildfires]]. [[José Mujica]], president of Uruguay, stated Piñera's low approval rates might be caused by a lack of "[[glamour (presentation)|glamour]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/mundo/uruguay/jose-mujica-de-repente-pinera-tiene-poco-glamour/2013-02-02/113112.html|title=José Mujica: "De repente Piñera tiene poco glamour"|trans-title=|language=|date=2 February 2013|website=Cooperativa.cl|access-date=19 December 2017}} In April 2012 ''[[The Economist]]'' described Piñera as being considered an "inept politician" by both the opposition and supporters.[http://www.economist.com/node/21552566 Progress and its discontents]. ''[[The Economist]]' The Chilean government responded by stating that ''The Economist's'' comment was disrespectful.{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/2012/04/13/535601/gobierno-le-responde-a-the-economist-y-califica-como-un-error-tratar-a-pinera-de-inepto.html|title=Gobierno responde a The Economist sobre epítetos a Presidente Piñera|trans-title=|language=|work=Emol|access-date=27 April 2016}} His lapses, errors and inconveniences have been labelled "piñericosas" in Chile,{{cite news|last=Saleh|first=Felipe|title=Por qué Piñera habla como telepredicador|trans-title=|language=|url=http://www.elmostrador.cl/noticias/pais/2011/03/07/por-que-pinera-habla-como-telepredicador/|access-date=5 December 2012|newspaper=El Mostrador|date=7 March 2011}} in a phenomenon comparable to [[Bushism]]s in the United States. Piñera notably confused the fictional character [[Robinson Crusoe]] with [[Alexander Selkirk]] while giving a speech on a state visit to [[Robinson Crusoe Island]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} In June 2013, after visiting President Obama in the White House,{{cite web|last1=Souza|first1=Pete|title=P060413PS-0549|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/9314668689/in/set-72157634692105189/|website=The White House Flickr Photostream|access-date=12 February 2015}} he said, "I'm going to sit at the President of the United States' desk," breaking the White House's political protocols. [[Alfredo Moreno Charme]], Minister of Foreign Affairs, said "How many other presidents have done the same?" and Obama responded, "This is the only one," causing laughter between those there. Piñera then justified his abrupt actions by stating his daughter was born in the United States.[http://www.ellitoral.com/index.php/diarios/2011/01/03/opinion/OPIN-06.html "Piñera volvió a meter la pata". ''El Litoral''. January 3, 2011] == Personal life == [[File:Http 22-02-2012 Primera Dama en Sn Clemente.jpg|left|thumb|Piñera and Morel in February 2012]] Piñera married [[Cecilia Morel]] in December 1973. They were neighbors in the Avenida Américo Vespucio, Santiago.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} They have four children, born in 1975, 1978, 1982 and 1984. All of them have university degrees.{{cite web|url=http://www.gobiernodechile.cl/presidente/en/|title=Gobierno de Chile|work=Gobierno de Chile|accessdate=27 April 2016}} Piñera is also a member of Washington D.C.-based think tank, the [[Inter-American Dialogue]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedialogue.org/experts/sebastian-pinera/|title=Inter-American Dialogue {{!}} Sebastián Piñera|website=www.thedialogue.org|access-date=19 April 2017}} {{clear}} == In popular culture == Actor [[Bob Gunton]] portrays Piñera in the 2015 film ''[[The 33 (film)|The 33]]'', directed by [[Patricia Riggen]]. ==Notes== {{notelist}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.gobiernodechile.cl/presidente/en}} * {{es icon}} [http://www.cidob.org/es/documentacion/biografias_lideres_politicos/america_del_sur/chile/sebastian_pinera_echenique Extended biography by CIDOB Foundation] * {{es icon}} [http://www.emol.com/especiales/_elecciones_2005/perfiles_pinera.htm Biographical notes, in Spanish] * {{es icon}} [http://www.genealog.cl/Chile/P.html#PINERA Genealogy of the Piñera family in Chile] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before={{nowrap|[[Michelle Bachelet]]}}}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of Chile]]|years=2010–2014}} {{s-aft|after={{nowrap|[[Michelle Bachelet]]}}}} {{s-bef|before={{nowrap|[[Michelle Bachelet]]}}}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of Chile]]|years=2018–present}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-dip}} {{s-bef|before=[[Peter O'Neill]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chair of the [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]]|years=2019}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Presidents of Chile}} {{Heads of State of the South America}} {{Current APEC Leaders}} {{Current UNASUR leaders}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pinera, Sebastian}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Chilean billionaires]] [[Category:Chilean businesspeople]] [[Category:Chilean economists]] [[Category:Chilean people of Asturian descent]] [[Category:Chilean people of Basque descent]] [[Category:Chilean people of Spanish descent]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Chile]] [[Category:Chilean Roman Catholics]] University of Chile alumni]] [[Category:Collars of the Order of Isabella the Catholic]] [[Category:Presidents of Chile]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} '''Shareholder ownership value''' (SOV) {{cite news|url=http://wgfa.wharton.upenn.edu/VillalongaAmit121004.pdf|title=How Do Family Ownership, Control, and Management Affect Firm Value?|last=Belén Villalonga Harvard Business School |first=Raphael Amit - The Wharton School |date=2004-12-01|work=The Wharton School|accessdate=2014-04-04}}{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M87oXwAACAAJ&dq=%22Shareholder+ownership+value%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MTM9U8nlBITqywPNs4GQCg&redir_esc=y|title= Obbligazione Convertibile, Panico Del 1907, Finanza Sostenibile, Valutazione, Scudo Fiscale, Subprime, Finanza Straordinaria |last=various|first=authors|date=2012-08-01|work= General Books LLC |accessdate=2014-03-04}} is a financial theory that developed internationally after the [[subprime mortgage crisis]].
It started at the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] by the MBA student [[Paolo G. Alberoni]] and published in 1994. The SOV theory argues there is a validity limit of [[William F. Sharpe]]'s [[capital asset pricing model|CAPM]]. CAPM fails to incorporate in the [[Weighted average cost of capital|WACC]] the decision power of majority shareholder (owner) that can affect the destination of the company/assets cash flows. The theory moves his base considering shareholder's power and [[total cost of ownership]].{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} In the paper, Alberoni shows evidence and structures a referenced framework demonstrating how the [[Stock exchange]] prices fails to capture the full value of assets in the long term and therefore undervalues them in the long run. Whilst in takeover there is a "premium paid" to majority shareholders vs minority shareholders. This Majority premium is essentially connected to the ability of the Majority Shareholder to influence how cash flows are used in the company The evidence has been gathered as follow: under common wisdom a company that dismisses real assets and leases them back gets benefits from tax breaks, better liquidity, etc. The SOV theory looks back and shows that "assets free" companies are more vulnerable to extreme shocks and have recorded performance in line with "asset loaded" companies in the same field. Therefore, there must be a "missing part" in the original valuation. The paper highlights how companies with assets in the long term can outperform and overcome economic and financial downturns, and are able to provide "real return" in excess of inflation with reduced volatility relative to asset free companies (who in a broad sense demand to shareholders to create a strategy for the cash flows generated by the sales of assets). ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Finance theories]] [[Category:Shareholders]] {{finance-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Spreckels Sugar Company''' is an [[United States|American]] [[sugar beet]] refiner that for many years controlled much of the [[West Coast of the United States|U.S. West Coast]] refined sugar market. It is currently headquartered in [[Brawley, California]].
==History== The Spreckels Sugar Company was founded by entrepreneur, industrialist, newspaper publisher, and railroad executive [[Claus Spreckels]] (1828–1908) in February 1899. He founded the [[company town]] of [[Spreckels, California]], just south of the city of [[Salinas, California]], in 1897, but his descendants began to relinquish control when they started selling homes in the community to the public c. 1925. In 1891, [[Henry O. Havemeyer]], who controlled The American Sugar Refining Company (The Sugar Trust), bought half of the stock of the Western Sugar Company, thus giving his company control of the Hawaiian sugar and of the markets west of the [[Mississippi River]]. When it was completed in 1899, Spreckels' "Factory 1" was the largest sugar refinery in the United States and the third-largest in the world. Shipping to and from the plant was mostly by a private Spreckels-owned narrow-gauge railroad system connecting to the docks at [[Moss Landing, California]]. The factory was just north of the [[Salinas River (California)|Salinas River]] at {{coord| 36|37|7|N| 121|39|5|W| type:landmark_region:US-CA| display=inline,title}}.
On Claus Spreckels' death, his second son [[Adolph B. Spreckels]] (1857–1924) assumed the management of Spreckels Sugar Company. Adolph's wife's nephew, [[Charles Edouard de Bretteville]], eventually took over as head of the company and in 1949 led a group that purchased control. In 1963, the family sold their interests to [[Domino Foods|Amstar]]. In 1987, a management team bought out the Spreckels Sugar Division; in 1996, it was sold to [[Imperial Sugar|Imperial Holly Corp.]] of [[Sugar Land, Texas]], who owned it until 2005 when it was sold to [[Southern Minnesota Beet Sugar Cooperative]] of [[Renville, Minnesota]].
Spreckels Boulevard outside Salinas, as well as Spreckels Road outside [[King City, California]] and Spreckels Boulevard in [[Manteca, California]], still bear witness to the mark Spreckels Sugar made in the area.<ref>https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2007/03/19/sugar-factory-stunk-to-olfactory/</ref>
American author [[John Steinbeck]] worked on ranches owned by Spreckels Sugar throughout the Salinas Valley in the early 1920s.
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.santacruzpl.org/history/places/spreck.shtml Santa Cruz Public Libraries "The Spreckels Era in Rio Del Mar, 1872--1922" by Allen Collins] *Historical marker at the Spreckels city limits. *{{Cite journal| last = Conway| first = Jimmie| title = Spreckels Sugar Company : the first fifty years| journal = Master's Theses, [[San Jose State University]]| date = 1999-01-01|url=http://scholarworks.sjsu.edu/etd_theses/1920/}}
==External links== *[http://www.spreckelssugar.com Official '''Spreckels Sugar Company''' website] *[http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt3m3nd07h/ Guide to the Western Sugar Refinery Records, 1871-1949] at [[The Bancroft Library]] - earlier version of company
[[Category:Sugar companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Imperial County, California]] [[Category:History of Monterey County, California]] [[Category:Salinas Valley]] [[Category:Food and drink companies established in 1899]] [[Category:1899 establishments in California]] [[Category:Business in Hawaii]]
